Emperor.

The.xxvii. Chapter.
But when it was judged yt Co^l. 4. ^
Aristarchus the Macedonian of Thessalia continuynge with us. And on ye next
day came we to Sidon. But Julius intreatynge Paul courteouslye, Actu. 24. c
and.28. b
suffered him to go unto his friends and to refr^sh himself. And when we had
launched thence, we sailed near by Cypers, because that ye winds were
contrary. And saylynge over the sea of Cilicia and Pamphilia, we came to
Lystra, which is [a cytie] of Lycia, and the Ce^turio finding there a ship
of Alexandria saylynge into Italye, he set us over therein. And when we sailed
slowly many days, and were scarce come against Gnidus, the wind forbyddynge
us, we sailed by Candy nigh unto Salmo, and scarcely saylynge by it we came unto
a place called Goodhauen, nigh where unto was the city Thalassa. When much
time was spente, and that saylynge was now yeopardous, because that fasting
was past, Paul comforted them, saying unto them: Ye men, I se that this
saylynge begins to be with danger and great damage, not only of the
ladynge and ship, Sirtes are parlous sa^dy places in the sea about the
coasts of Africa
Sirtes, the vessel let down, they were so carried. And as we had been tossed
with a great tempest they made an out cast on the next day, and the third day
they thrue away the tacklynges of the ship with their own hands. And when
another the Son nor the stars appeared in many days, and no small tempest
lay upon us, than was now the hope of all our sauegarde taken away. And when
there Actu. 25. b
thou must be brought before the Act. 25. b
Emperor, and behold, God has given the all them yt sail with the.
Wherefore ye men be of good chere, for I trust in God it shall so be as it is
said unto me: Actu. 28. a
But we must come into a certain I Will. But after that the fourtenth night was
come as we sailed in Adria, about the mydnyght did the shypme^ deem some
region to appear unto them. The which also casting ou^ the lead, they fande
it twenty feddo^s and gone a little from thence, they fande it souldyours the
rope of the boat insu^der, and let it fall. And when it began to become light,
Paul prayed them all to take bread, saying: This day is the fourtenth day
yt ye waiting abide fasting, taking nothing, wherefore I pray you to take
meat for your health: Math. 10. d Luce. 12. a
for of none of your head shall one here perysh. And when he had said this,
Marc. 6. c and.8. a Ioh. 6. a 1. Tim. 4. a
taking bread he thanked God in the presence of all, and when he had broken
it, he began to eat. And they all being of good chere, began to land, and
the other they carried upon tables, and some upon those things that were in the
ship. And thus it came to pass that all the souls escaped to land.

The.xxviii. Chapter.
ANd wha^ we were escaped, Actu. 27. c
was called Melite. And the The Romans called al nations Barbarous that were
not her Romans nor Greeks
Barbarous people showed us no small kyndnesse. For a fire kyndled they
refreshed us all because of the rain that lay upon us, and cold. But when
Paul had gathered a little bo^del of styckes and had laid it upon the fire,
when a vyper came out for the heat, she lepte upon his hand. But when the
Barbarous people saw the beast hanging at his hand, they said to each other:
Surely this man is a man slayer, whom though he have escaped the sea,
vengeance suffers not to live. And he truly shaking the beast of into the
fire, Luce. 10. ^
suffered no harm. But they thought he should have swollen, and suddenly fallen
and dyed. And they waiting long, and seeing no evil happen in him, they
turnynge themselves, Actu. 14. ^
said him to be a God. And in those quarters were the lands of the ruler of
the I Will, by name Publius, which lodgyng us entreated us courteously three days.
And it fortuned ye father of Publius to lie diseased of Math. 8. b
the fevers and bloody flux. Unto whom Paul went in. And when he had
prayed, and had laid [hys] hands upon him, he healed him. The which being
done, all they in the I Will that had diseases, came to him and were healed. Which
also endued us with great honor, and laded us saylynge with things that
were necessary. And after three months we sailed in a ship of Alexandria,
which had wyntred in the I Will, whose badge was Castor and Pollux. And when we
ca^ to Syracusa, we abode there three days. And thence saylynge about we came
to Rhegium. And after one day, the southwynde blowynge, we came to Puteolis ye
second day. Where (brethren being found) we were prayed to abide with the^
seven days, and so we came to Rome. And when the brethren thence had herd of
us, Actu. 15. a
they met us until Forum Appii and Three tauerns, The which when Paul had
seen, thanking God, he gat a courage. But when we came to Rome, the Centurio
took the presoners unto ye chief captain of the host. Actu. 24. c and.^7. a
But it was granted unto Paul to abide by himself with a souldyour keeping
Actu. 24. b and.25. b
I doing nothing against the people, or the costume of ye fathers, Actu. 23. c
am delivered bound at Jerusalem into ye hands of the Romans. The which when
they had examined me, they would have let me go, because there was no cause of
death in me. But ye Jews gaynsayenge, I was compelled to appeal unto the
Emperor, not as having ought to accuse my people of. For this cause therefore
desired I to se and speak with you. For it is Actu. 23* ^ and.26. a
for the hope of Israel that I am bound about with this cheyne. But they
said unto him: We have another received letters of the from Iewry, another did
any of the brethren coming show or speak any evil of the. But we pray the
to hear of thyselfe what thou thynkest. For we know of this sect that every
where Luce. ^. ^
it is gaynsayde. But when they had appointed him a day, there came many to him
into his lodging, unto whom he wytnessynge expouned the kingdom of God, and
was persuadynge them of Jesus out of Gene. 3. ^
Moses and ye prophets from ye morning until the evening. Actu. 17. a
And some believed those things that were spoken, but some believed not. And
Esaias. 6. b Mat. 1^. b Marc. 4. a Luce. 8. b Ioha^. 12. e Roma. 1^. ^
With the ear shall ye hear, and ye shall not understand: and seeing shall
ye se, and not perceive: For this peoples heart is waxe^ gross, and with their
ears have they herd hardely and their eyes have they closed: lest happily
they se with their eyes, and hear with their ears, and understand with the
heart, and be turned, and I heal them. Be it therefore known unto you that
unto the Heythen is this salvation of God sent, and they shall hear it. And
wha^ he had said these things, the Jews went out from him, questeonynge much
among themselves. But he abode two whole year in his hired lodging, and
received al them that came to him, preaching the kingdom of God, and
teaching the things that be of ye LORD Jesus Christ with al boldness,
without forbyddynge.

The end of the Acts of the Apostles.
The Epistle of the Apostle S. Paul to the Romans.
The first Chapter.
Paul the seruau^te of Jesus Actu. 1^. a
put aparte into ye Gospel of God, which Deuteronomy. 18. c Actu. 2^. d
he had promised before by his prophets in ye holy scriptures, of his son,
which becam unto him Math. 1. a 2. Tim. 2. a
of the sede of David after ye flesh: Which was before declared the son of
God in power after ye sprete of hallowynge, from the resurrection of ye dead
of Jesus Christ our LORD: by who^ Actu. 9. c
we have received grace and Apostleshippe to be obedient unto faith among al
nations for his name: In who^ ye also are called of Jesus Christ. To al yt are
beloved of God at Rome, (called saints.) 1. Cori. 1. a Gala. ^. ^
Grace be unto you, and peace from God ye father and our LORD Jesus Christ First
of al truly I give thanks to my God through Jesus Christ for you al, because
your faith is publyshed in all the world. For God ( Ioh. 4. c 2. Tim 4. ^

Collos. 1. a Iere. 10. d

yourney Philip. 1. ^ Collos. 1. a Iere. 10. d
in the will of God Act. 28. c

by ye faith of yours and mine which is among us. Actu. 16. a
let he thereto) yt I might have some fruit in you, like as in the other
Heythen also. I am detter to the Greeks, and to ye Barbarous: to the wise, and
to ye unwise: So yt in me there is readynesse to preach ye Gospel unto you also
which be at Rome. Eccli. 41. c 2. Tim. 1. b
For I am not ashamed of the Gospel. For why* it is ^. Cori. 1, c
the power of God into salvation for every beleuer, for ye Jew first and for
ye Greek. For in it is ye righteousness of God declared out of faith into
faith. As it is written: ^bac. 2. a Gala. 3 a Heb. 1^. d
The ryghteous shall live of faith. For the wrath of God is declared from

truth of God in unrighteousness: For ye thing of God which is known, is
manifest in them: Actu. 14. c
For God has showed it the^. Heb. 11. a
For ye invisible things of him yt be understood Psalm. 18. a
are beholden out of the creature of ye world, by those things that are made:
Ye even his everlasting power and Godheade, so yt they are not to be excused.
Deuteronomy. 28. c
their foolysh heart was darkened: For they saying themselves to be wise,
became foolysh. Psalm. 105. c Iere. 2. d
They changed also ye glory of ye incorruptible God in to the similitude of
the image of a corruptible man, and of fethred fowls, and of fourefooted
beasts, and of Bell. d.
serpents. 2. Reg. 24 a Ezech. 14 a
Wherefore God gave them over into the lusts of their heart, even into

altered ye truth of God into lesynge, and worshipped and served ye creature,
rather tha^ the maker, which is blessed for ever, Ame^. Therefore god Leui. 18. c
for their weme^ changed ye use of nature into ye use which is against nature.
Likewise also ye me^ (ye natural use of ye weme^ being left) burned in lusts
among themselves, me^ upon me^ workyng fylthynesse, and receauyng in to
themselves yt due reward of their error. Prou. 1. c Actu. ^, e
And as they regarded not to have god in knowledge, God gave the^ over into a
lewd mind, yt they might do those things which are not convenient: being
filled with all iniquite, malice, fornicacion, covetousness, wickedness, full of
envy, ma^slaughters, co^te^cion, gyle, frowardness, preuy accusers,

The.ii. Chapter.
Wherefore you art not to be excused Math. 7. a
iudgest. For in yt 2. Reg. 12. b
you iudgest another, you condemnest thy self: For thou thyselfe that iudgest,
do even ye same things. For we know that ye judgment of God is
(according to the truth) against those that do such things. Thynkest thou
this O thou every man that iudgest the^ which do such things and do ye same
[thyselfe,] yt you shall escape ye judgment of God? Or dispysest you the riches
of his goodness and patience and long sufferynge? Esa^. 30. c Actu. 1^. ^
Know you not yt the loving kyndnesse of God leads the to repentance? But
you after thy stubburnesse and impenitent heart, hordest up wrath unto thyselfe
in ye day of wrath and of declarynge of ye ryghteous judgment of God, Psalm.
61. b
which shall reward every man according to his works: eue^ glory, and

doing) seek everlasting life: but unto such as be of conte^cion and that 2.
Tessa. 1. b
agree not unto the truth but believe unrighteousness, shall come wrath and
indignacio^, trouble and anguysh against every soul of man doing evil, of
the Jew first and of the Greek. But glory and honor and peace unto every one
doing Actu. ^0. d Ephe. 6. a Gala. 2. a
For there is no accepting of persons with God. For whosoever have sinned without
law, shall perysh without law. And who soever have sinned in ye law, shall be
judged by ye law. Math. 7. c Luce. 6. ^ Jacob. 1. ^
For ye hearers of ye law be not righteous with God, but ye doers of ye law
shall be made ryghteous. For wha^ the Heythe^ yt have not the law, do naturally
those things yt belong to the law, the same having no law be a law unto
themselves, which declare the work of ye law written in their hearts, their
conscience bearyng witness unto the^, and of thoughts accusynge or excusing
among them selves, in the day Mat. 25. c
when God shall judge the secrets of men by Jesus Christ, according to my
Gospel. But if Ioha^. 8. c
you be named a Jew, and restest in the law, and make thy boast in God, and
know his will, and being instruct by the law alowest the things that be
more profitable, beleuest thyselfe to be a leader of the blind, a light of
the^ that be in darkness, an instructour of the unwise, a master of young
babes, having the ensample of knowledge and of the truth in the law. Thou
therefore ye Math. ^. ^
Thou that preachest not to steal stealest thy self. Thou that say me^
should not break wedlock, breadest wedlock thyselfe. Thou that abhorrest
Idols, co^mittest sacrilege. Thou that make boast in ye law, by the
transgression of the law dishonourest God. For through you is the name of God
blasphemed among the Heythen, Esa. 52. a Ezech. 36 d
as it is written. Circumcision truly avails, if thou observe the law: But
if thou be a tra^sgressoure of the law, thy circumcision is become
uncircumcision. If the uncircumcision therefore do keep the ryghteousnesses of
the law, shall not his uncircumcision be reputed for circumcision? And (that by
nature is uncircumcision) perfourmynge ye law, shall it judge the, which through
the lettre and circumcision art a transgressour of the law? For he is not a
Jew which is outward, another is it circumcision that is outwardly in the
flesh: Ioha^. 8. d Roma. 9. a
but he is a Jew which is in secret, and Coll. 2. b
the circumcision of the heart in sprete, not in ye letter, whose praise is not
of me^, but of God.

The.iii. Chapter.
Roma. 9. a
because the speches of God were committed unto the^. For ^. Tim. 2. a
what, if some of them believed not? Has their unbelief made the promise of God
void? God forbid. Ioh. 3* ^
God is true, but Psalm 115. a
every man a liar, as it is written: Psalm. 50. a
That you may be made ryghteous in thy words, and overcome when thou art
judged. But if our iniquite praise the righteousness of God, what shall we
say? Is God unrighteous, yt sends wrath? I speak after the manner of man.
God forbid. Else how shall God judge this world? For if the truth of god has
in my lie ben plenteous to his glory, why am I yet also judged as a sinner? And
not (as we be blasphemed, and as some report that we should say) let us do
evil that good may come? Whose damnacion is just. Psalm. 13. a and.15. a
there is not one ryghteous, there is not one of understanding, there is not one
seeking after God. They are all gone aside, they are all together become
unprofitable, there is not one that does good, there is not so much as one.

Their throat is an open sepulcher, with their tunges have they dealte
deceatfully, the poison of Psalm. 19. ^
adders is under their lyppes. Psalm. 9. ^
Whose mouth is full of cursynge and bytternesse, Prou. 1. a
their fete swyfte to shed blood. Esa. 59. a

known, Psalm. 35. a
the fear of God is not before their eyes. But we know, that what things so

every mouth may be stopped, and that all the world may be subdued unto God,
Gala. ^. ^
because that out of the deeds of the law every flesh shall not be justified
before him. Heb. 7. ^
For by the law is the knowledge of sin. But now without the law is the
righteousness of God declared, having witness of the law and the prophets.
The righteousness of God comes through the faith of Jesus Christ into all
and upon all that believe in him. For there is no difference. Esaias. 53. c
But they are justified freely by his grace, through the redemption that is in
Christ Jesus, whom God has set forth Hebr. 5. a
an optayner of mercy through faith in his blood, to the declarynge of his
righteousness, for the remission of sins going before in the sufferynge of
God, to the declarynge of his righteousness in this time, that HE may be
ryghteous and the iustifyer of him, which is of ye faith of Jesus Christ. Where
is than thy reioycyng? It is excluded. By what law? Of deeds? No, but by ye
law of faith For Gala. 2. c
we hold that a man is justified by faith without the works of ye law. Or is
God the God of the Jews only? Is he not also the God of ye Heythen? Yet of ye
Heythen also For certainly it is one God, that iustifyeth the circuncisio^ of
faith, and the uncircumcision by faith. Do we therefore destroy the law by
faith? God forbid. But we maynteyne the law.

The.v. Chapter.
Esaias. 26. a
justified through faith, may have, Ioh. 16. d

For why dyed Christ for the ungodly, when we were yet weak according to the

But God sets forth his love in us: for if Christ dyed for us, when we were
yet sinners according to the time, much more now therefore we being justified
in his blood, shall be safe from wrath by him. For if wha^ we were Gene. 3. ^
Wherefore like as by one man sin entered into this world, and death by sin,
even so also went death through into all men, in that all have sinned. For
until the law was sin in the world. But sin was not imputed, wha^ there
was not a law. Nevertheless death reigned from Ada^ until Moses, ye even
into the^ ye sinned, after ye similitude of ye tra^sgression of Ada^, which is
the image of him for to come. But ye gift also is not as ye trespass. For if
many be dead through ye trespase of one: much more has the grace and gift of
God ben plenteous into many in the favor of one man Jesus Christ. The Ioha^.
4. ^
gift also is not so as by one Likewise therefore as by ye trespass of one
into all men into condemnacion: even so also by the righteousness of one into
all men into the iustifyenge of life. For like as by the disobedience of one
man many were made sinners. Even so also by the obedience of one many shall be
made ryghteous. Gala. 3. c
The law entered in ye sin should increace. Luce. 7. c
But where sin abounded, there was grace also more plenteous. That like as
sin raygned into death: even so grace also might raygne through
righteousness into everlasting life, by Jesus Christ our LORD.

The.vi. Chapter.
Gala. 3. ^ Collo. 2. b ^. Petri. 3. c
Know ye not brethren, that we who so ever be baptized in Christ Jesus, are
baptized in his death? For we are buried together with him through baptyme in
to death: That like as Christ rose from the dead through the glory of the
father, Ephesians. 4. c Collo. 3. a Hebre. 9 c
even so we also should walk in the newness of life. For if we be grafted
unto the similitude of his death, we shall belong to ye resurreccion also:
Knowing this moreover, yt our old man is crucified, yt the body of sin may
be destroyed, yt from he^ceforth we should not serve syn 1. Pet. 4. a
For he yt is dead, is made ryghteous from sin. 2. Petri. 2. b
But if we be dead with Christ, we believe, yt we shall also live together with
him: knowing, Apoc. 1. d
yt Christ rysyng again from ye dead, dies not now, death shall not have
dominion over him any more. For as touching that he dyed, he dyed from sin
once: But as touching that he lives, he lives unto God. Eue^ so ye also
think your selves drade from sin, but living unto God in Christ Jesus. Let
not sin therefore reygne in your mortal body, yt ye should obey unto ye lusts
of it: Another give ye over your members weapens of iniquite unto sin, but
give over your selves unto God, as they that of dead are living: And your
members the weapens of righteousness unto God. For sin shall not have
dominion of you: for ye are not under the law, but under grace. Ioh. 8. c 2.
Petri. ^ ^
Know ye not, that to whom ye give over your selves servants to obey, his
servants ye be to whom ye obey, whether of sin unto death, or of obedience
unto righteousness? But God be thanked, that ye were the servants of sin,
but have out of the heart obeyed unto that fashion of doctrine, wherein ye are.
Ye being delivered from sin, are become the servants of ryghteousnes. I
speak after the manner of me^, because of ye infirmite of your flesh. For like
as ye have given over your members to serve uncleanness and iniquite to iniquite:
eue^ so now give over your me^bres to righteousness into hallowynge. For when
ye were servants of sin ye were void of righteousness. What fruit
therefore had ye than in those things wherein ye be now ashamed? For the end
of the^ is death. But now ye being delivered from sin, and become servants
unto God, have your fruit into hallowynge, but the end everlasting life.
Gene. 2. c Roma. 5. b
For death is ye wages of sin* but everlasting life is the grace of God in
Christ Jesus our LORD.

The.vii. Chapter.
1. Cori. 7. d
For a woman which is under an husband, is bound unto the law, the husband
living. But if her husband dye, she is lowsed from the law of the husband.
Therefore while the man lives she shall be called a wedlock breaker, Math. 5. d
if she be with another husband. But if her husband dye, she is delivered from
the law of the husband: so that she is not a wedlockbreaker if she be with
another husband. And so my brethren, ye also are dead unto the law by the
body of Christ, yt ye should be another man's, which is risen again from the
dead, that ye may bring forth fruit unto God. For when we were in ye flesh,
the lusts of sins (which were by the law) wrought in our members, that they
should bring forth fruit unto death. But now are we lowsed from the law of
death, wherein we were holde^, so yt we should serve in ye newness of the
sprete, and not in ye say therefore? Is the law sin? God forbid.
Nevertheless I knew not Exo. ^^. c Deuteronomy. 5. c
Thou shalt not lust. But when occasion was taken, by the commandment sin
wroughte in me all concupiscence. For without the law sin was dead. But I
lived without law sometime. Nevertheless when the commandment was come,
sin reuyued: but I am dead. And the same commandment which was unto
life, was found unto me to be unto death. For sin by occasion taken through
the commandment deceived me, and by the same did it kill. Esaias. 48. d 1. Tim.
1. b
The law therefore is in deed holy, and ye commandment holy, and just, and
good. Is that therefore which is good become death unto me? God forbid. But
sin that it might appear sin, has wrought me death through good, that
sin might be out of measure sinful by the commandment. For we know that
the law is spiritual, but I am carnal, Esa. 52. ^
sold under sin. For that I do, I understand not. For I do not that good
which I will, but that evil which I hate, do I. If I than do that which I will
not, I consent unto the law, that it is good. Nevertheless now do not I it,
but Genesis 6. a
flesh. For to will lies upon me: but to fulfill the good, do I not find.
For I do not the good, that I will: but the evil that I will not, that do I.
But if I do it that I will not, now do not I it, but the sin that dwells in
me. I find therefore a law, that there cleueth euel unto me, even unto me
willing to do good. For I have a delight unto the law of God after the inward
man: But in my members I se another law, repugnaunt unto the law of my mind,
and holding me captyue in the law of sin, which is in my members. Unhappy
man that I am, who shall deliver me from the body of this death? The grace of
God through Jesus Christ our LORD. I therefore myself in mind serve ye law of
god but in the flesh the law of sin.

The.viii. Chapter.
Ioh. 8. c Gala. 4 a
from the law of sin and of death. Heb. 7. c
For where as it was impossible unto ye law in that it was made weak through
the flesh, God sendynge his son into the symilitude of ye flesh of sin,
out of 2. Cori. 5. c
sin also has damned sin in the flesh, that the righteousness of the law
might be fulfilled in us, which walk not after the flesh, but after the
sprete. For they that be after the flesh, mind those things that be of ye
flesh: But they that be after the sprete, mind those things that are of the
sprete. For the prudence of the flesh, is death: but ye prudence of ye sprete,
is life and peace. For why? the wysedo^ of the flesh is enemy unto God: Esa.
55. c
For it is not subdued unto ye law of God, for it can not. They that be in the
flesh, can not please God. Nevertheless ye are not in ye flesh, but in the
sprete, if so be yet yt the sprete of God dwell in you. If any man have not the
sprete of Christ, ye same is not his. But if Christ be in you, the body truly
is dead, because of sin, but the sprete lives for righteousness sake. If
so be that ye sprete Gala. 4. a 2. Tim. 1. ^
For ye have not received ye sprete of bondage again in fear, but ye have
received the sprete of adopcio^ of the children of God, in the which we cry:
Abba, father. For 2. Cori. 1. c and.5. a Ephe. 1. b
the same spret bears record unto our sprete, yt we be ye children of God.
But if we be ye children, we are heirs also: heirs truly of God, heirs
together with Christ: If so be yet yt we suffer together, yt we may also be
glorified together. Math. 5. a 2. Cori. 4. b 1. Ioha^. 3. a
For I suppose, that the sufferynges of this time are not worthy unto ye glory
to come, which shall be showed in us. 2. Cori. 5. a
For the longing of the creature looks for the open declarynge of the
children of God. For the creature is subdued unto v^nite, not willing, but for
his sake that has subdued it in hope because the same creature also shall be
delivered from ye bondage of corrupcio^, into the lyberte of ye glory of the
children of God. For we know, that every creature groneth, and Ioh. 16. c
trauaileth hitherto Not only it, but we also our selves, having ye first
fruits of ye sprete, groan also within our selves for ye adopcion of ye
children of God, lokynge for ye rede^pcion of our body. For we are saved by
hope. Hebre. 1. a
But hope that is seen is not hope: For how hops a man for yt which he
seyeth? But if we hope for ye which we se Esa. 26. c
but the sprete it self makes intercession for us with gronynges
vnoutspeakeable. Iere. 17. b
He that searches the hearts, knows what the sprete desires, for he makes
intercession for the saints according to the peasure of God. But we know,
that unto them which love God, all things work together unto goood. To them
that of purpose are called saints. For those whom he knew before, has he
also predestinate to be made like the image of his son, that he himself
might be the first begotten among many brethren. But those whom he has
predestynate, the same has he called also. And them whom he has called,
has he also justified: Them whom he has justified, has he also magnifyed.
(...). 14. a Esaias. ^^. b
If God be on our side, who can be against us? Gene. ^^. ^ Esaias. 5^ ^
Which also has not spared his own son, but has given him over for us
all. How has he not also given us all things with him? Who will bring any
accusacion against the chosen of God? It is God that iustifyeth, who is he that
can condemn? It is Christ Jesus that dyed, ye^ even he that rose, which is
also at the right hand of God, which likewise makes intercession for us Who
shall therefore separate us from the love of Christ? Trouble? or anguysh? or
derth? or nakedness? or parell? or persecucion, or swearde? As it is written,
that: Psalm. 4^. ^
For thy sake are we killed all the day long, we are counted as slaughter
sheep. But in all these we overcome, because of him that has loved us. For
sure I am, that another death, nor life, another angels, nor principates, nor
powers, another things present, nor things to come, another strength, another
heyght, nor loweth, another any creature, shall be able to separate us from the
love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our LORD.

The.ix. Chapter.
I Speak ye truth in Christ For Exodus 3^ ^

which is God above all things, blessed for ever. Amen. But not that the word
of God has failed. Roma. 2. c
For all they that be of the circumcision of Israel are not Israelites: Gala. 4.
c
Another be they all children yt are the sede of Abraham: Genesis 22. b
But in Isaac shall ye sede be called unto the: That is, they that be the
children of the flesh, are not children of God, but they that be children of
the promise are counted in the sede. For this is a word of promise: Gen^. 18. b
After this time will I come, and Sara Gene. 25. c
Rebecca also having of one lyenge by of Isaac our father. For when they were
not yet borne, or had done any thing good or evil, that the purpose of God
might abide according to the eleccion, not of works but of ye caller was it
said unto her: ye, The greater shall serve ye less. As it is written: Mala. 1. ^
I have loved Jacob, but Esau have I hated. What shall we say therefore? Is there
unrighteousness with God? God forbid. For he says unto Moses: Exodi. 33. b
I will have mercy on who^ I have mercy, and have compassion on whom I will have
compassion. It is not therefore of the wyller, another of the runner, but of God
the shewer of mercy. Exodus 9. c
For the sc^ipture says unto Pharao: That for this same thing have I steared
the up, that I may show my power in the, and that my name may be declared in
the whole earth. Therefore has he mercy on whom he will: and whom he will, he
hardens. Thou say therefore unto Esa. ^^. b and.64. ^
For who does wythstande his will? O man, who art thou that answerest unto God?
Says the work to him that made it: Why have thou made me thus? Iere. 18. a
Eccli. 33. b 2. Tim 2. c
Has not the potter power of the claye to make of the same lompe, some vessel
truly unto honor, but some to dishonor? If so be that God willing to show
wrath and to declare his power* suffered in much patience the vessels of wrath
mete for destruction, that he might declare the riches of his glory into the
vessels of mercy, which he has prepared unto glory: Whom also he has called,
not only us of the Jews, but also of the Heythen, as he says in Osee: Osee.
1. b and.2. a 1. Petri. 2 b
I will call not my people, my people: and the not beloved, the beloved: And

If the nombre of the children of Is^aell be as ye sonde of the sea, the

before: E^^. 1. b
Except the LORD Sabbath had left us sede, we had been made as Sodoma, and
should have been like as Gomorra. What shall we say therefore? That ye Heythen
which followed not righteousness, have overtaken ryghteousnes (but that
righteousness which is of faith.) But Israel in followynge the law of
righteousness, attained not unto the law of righteousness Why so? Because not
of faith, but as it were of works. For they have stombled upon the stomblyng
stone. As it is written: Esa. 28. ^
Behold, I lay in Sion a stone of stomblynge, and a rock of offendynge: And
every one that believes in him, shall not be confounded.

The.x. Chapter.
Roma. 9. d Gala. 4. b
they have in deed a zele of God, but not according to knowledge. For they not
knowing the righteousness of God, and seeking to set up their own, are not

For the end of the law is Christ unto salvation to every beleuer. For Moses
has written, Leui. 13. a Gala. 3. b
that the man which does ye righteousness that is in the law, shall live in
it. But the righteousness which is of faith, says thus: Deuteronomy. 30. c
Do not thou say in thine heart: Who shall go up into heaven. (That is, to
bring down Christ.) Or who shall go down into ye depth? (That is, to call up
Christ again from the dead.) But what says ye scripture? The word is nigh
in thy mouth and in thy heart. This is the word of faith that we preach. For
if thou knowledge ye LORD Jesus in thy mouth, and beleuest in thy heart, that
God has raised him up from the dead, thou shall be safe. For with the heart
is it believed unto righteousness, but with the mouth is it knowleged unto
salvation. For ye scripture says: Esaias. 28. c
Every one ye believes on him, shall not be confounded. For there is no
difference of ye Jew and of the Greek. For one is LORD of all, rich unto all
ye call upon him. Joel. ^. f Actu. ^. b and.22. b

The.xi. Chapter.
Iere, 31. f
Has god thrust out his people? That be far. For I also am an Israelite of
ye sede of Abraham of the trybe of Ben Iamin. God has not thrust out his
people, whom he knew before. Or wot ye not what ye scripture says in
Elias, how he makes intercession unto God against Israel. 3. Reg. 19 c
LORD, they have slain thy prophets, they have dygged down thine altares,

unto him? ^. Reg. 19. d
I have reserved unto me seven thousand of men, which have not bowed ye knees

the eleccion of ye grace of God. Deuteronomy. 9. a

olyue tree, auaunce not thyselfe against ye branches. For if thou do boast,

The.xiii. Chapter.
1. Pet. 2. b Sap. 6. a
For there is no power but of god: And they that be, are ordined of God.
Therefore he that resysteth ye power, resysteth the ordinance of God: But they
that do resyste it, they get themselves da^nacion. For rulers are not to be
feared for the good work, but the euel. But wylt thou not fear the power? do
good, and thou shall have praise of it: for he is a mynister of God unto the in
good. But if thou do evil, fear: For he bears not the swearde for
naught: For he is ye mynister of God, an aue^ger in ye wrath unto him that does
evil. And therefore be submytted unto the necessite not only because of the
wrath, but also for the conscience sake. For therefore do ye also give tributes:
For they are Gods ministers, serving Math. 17. d and. 22. c
Give therefore unto every one that are due: unto whom trybute, trybute: unto
whom costume, costume: unto who^ fear, fear: unto whom honor, honor.

thou shalt not commytte aduoutrye, thou shall not kyl, thou shalt not

we did believe. The night is past, but the day is come near. Collo. 3. ^

The.xiiii. Chapter.
Jacob. 4. b
Who art thou that iudgest another man's servant? He stands or falls unto
his LORD: but he shall stand. For God is able to make him stand For some one
judges between day and day, but another judges every day like: Collos. 2. c
Let every man be full in his meaning. He that regards ye day, he regards
it unto the LORD: And he that eats, eats unto the LORD: for he gives
thanks unto God. And he that eats not, eats not unto the LORD, and gives
thanks unto God. For none of us lives unto himself, and noman dies unto
himself. Whether we live therefore, we live unto the LORD: Whether we dye, we
dye unto the LORD. Therefore whether we live, or whether we dye, we be Actu. 2.
d Phili. 2. a
LORD both over the quick and dead. But what iudgest thou thy brother? or why
despysest thou thy brother? Gala. 6. ^
For we all shall stand before the judgment seat of Christ. For it is

I live says the LORD, for all knees shall be bowed unto me, and al tunge

I am sure, and trust in the LORD Jesus, that there is nothing commune by it
self, save unto him that judges it to be commune, unto him is it commune. For
if thy brother is made sorrowful for the meats sake, now do thou not walk
after charity. Destroy not thou him with Tit. ^. ^
All things truly are clean, but it is evil unto the man that eats wych
offendicle. 1. Corin. 8. ^
It is better not to eat flesh, and not to drink wine, nor wherein thy
brother stombleth or is offended, or is made weak. The faith that thou have by
thyselfe, have it before God. Happy is he that judges not himself, in it that
he allows. But he that puts difference, if he shall eat, he is damned:
because it is not of faith. Titu^. 1. c
For all that is not of faith, is sin.

The.xv. Chapter.
Gala. 6. a
we that are strong ought to sustain ye weakness of them that are not
strong, and not to stand in our own conceate. Let every one of you please
his neighbor unto good, to edifyenge. For Christ pleased not himself, but as
it is written: Psalm. 68. b
The rebukes of the rebukynge the, did fall upon me. Roma. 4. d
For what things so ever are written, they are written to our doctrine, that
by patience 1. Mac. 12. b
and consolacion of the scriptures, we may have hope. But the God of patience
and consolacion give you to understand one thing one toward another, after
Jesus Christ, that ye one minded may praise God with one mouth and the father
of our LORD Jesus Christ. Wherefore receive ye each other, as Christ also
has received you to the honor of God For I say Jesus Christus to have been
the mynister of circumcision for the truth of God, to confirm the promyses of
the fathers: but the Heythen to praise God upon mercy, as it is written. ^.
Reg. 21. g Psalm. 17. c
Therefore shall I praise the among the Heythen LORD, and I shall sing unto
thy name. And again he says: Deuteronomy. ^2. f
Rejoice ye Heythe^ with his people. And again: Psalm. 11^. a
All ye Heythen praise the LORD, and all ye people magnifye him. And again
Esaias. 1^. b
There shall be the root of Iesse, and he that shall rise to rule the Gentyles,
in him shall the Heythen trust. But the God of all hope fill you with all joy
and peace in beleuynge, that ye may ouerflowe in hope in the power of the holy
ghost. But I myself also ame sure of you brethren, that you also are full of
love, filled with al knowledge, in so much that ye be able to admonyshe each
other. But I have written more boldly unto you brethren, partly, as bringing
you to mind, because of the grace that is given me of God, that I should be a
minister of Christ Jesus among the Heythen, hallowynge the gospel of God, that
there be an offering of the Heythen acceptable and sanctified in the holy
gooste. I have therefore praise unto God in Christ Jesus. For I darre Actu. 1. ^
2. Pet. 1. ^
has not done by me, to the obedience of the Heythen, with word and deeds, by
the power of tokens and wonders, by the power of the holy ghost, in so much
that from Jerusalem round about until Illyricum I have filled [all] with the
Gospel of Christ. But I have so preached this Gospel, not where Christ is
named, (lest I should build upon another man's fundamente), but as it is
written: Esaias. 52. c
Unto whom it was not showed of him, they shall se: and they that have not
herd of him, shall understand. For the which cause also I was greatly let to
come unto you, and was forbidden hitherto. But now having no more rowme in
these quarters, but having a desire of many years now paste to come unto
you, when I shall begin to yournye in to Spain, I trust that going by I
shall se you, and be brought thither of you, if I shall have first partly
enjoyed Actu. 11. c 1. Cori. 16. a 2. Cor. 8. a and.9. a
hand-reachynge unto the poor saints, that be at Jerusalem: for it has
pleased them, and they are their detters. 1. Cor. 9. d Gala. 6. a
For if the Heythen are become partakers of their spiritual things, they
ought also to ministre unto them in carnal things. When I therefore shall have
fynyshed this, and shall have sealed them this fruit, I shall yourney by you
into Spain. But I know, that coming unto you, I shall come with the
abundaunce of the bless of the Gospel of Christ. I pray you therefore
brethren through our LORD Jesus Christ, and through the love of the holy
ghost, that ye help me in prayers for me unto God, that I may be delivered of
the unfaithful, that are in Iewrye, and that the offering of my willing
service may become accepacceptable unto the saints in Jerusalem: that with
joy I may come unto you, by the will of God, that I may be refreshed with
you. The God 1. Cor. ^
of peace be with you. Amen.

The.xvi. Chapter.
I Commend unto you Phebe Actu. 18. ^ 2. Tim. 4. c
Prisca and Aquila my helpers in Christ Jesus, (which have laid down their
necks for my life, unto whom not I only do give thanks, but all the
congregacions of the Heythen also,) and their household congregacyon. Great
Epenetus beloved unto me, which is the fyrstlynge in Christ Jesus of the
congregation of Asia. Great Mary that has labored much among us. Great
Andronicus and Iunia my cosyns and fellowpresoners, which are renowned among
the Apostles, which were also before me in Christ. Salute Ampliatus my most
beloved in the LORD. Salute Vrbane our helper in Christ Jesus, and Stachys my
beloved. Salute Apelles the approved in Christ. Salute them that be of which
labor in the LORD. Salute Perside ye most beloved, which has labored much
in the LORD. Salute Rufus ye chosen in ye LORD and his mother and mine. Great
Asyncritus, Phlego^, Hermes, Patrobas, Herman, and the brethren that are with
them. Great Philologus, and Iulia, Nereus and his sister, and Olimpias, and all
the saints that are with them. 2. Cori. 13. c
Salute each other with a holy kiss. All the congregacions of Christ great you.
Collo. ^. b Titu. ^. b
But I beseke you brethren yt ye mark them that make divisions and offenses,
beside the doctrine that ye have learned, and avoid them. For such serve not
Christ our LORD, but Philip. 3. c
their belly: and by sweet words and blessings they myscary the hearts of the
innocent. For your obedience is publyshed in every place. I rejoice therefore
of Math. 10. b
But I will have you to be wise in the good thing, and simple in the evil.
And ye God of peace tread Satan quyckely under your fete. The grace of our
LORD Jesus Christ be with you. Actu. 16. a Phili. 2. b
Timotheus my helper saluteth you, and Actu. 13. a
Lucius, and Act. 17. a
Jason, and Act. 20. a
Sosipater my cosins. I Tertius that have written this epistle in the LORD
salute you. 1. Cor. 1. b
Gaius mine ooste and of all the congregation saluteth you. Eras^us the
treasurer of the city, and Quartus a brother great you. The grace of our
LORD Jesus Christ be with you all. Amen.

To him that is able to stablyshe you according to my Gospel and the
preaching of Jesus Christ, after ye reuelacion of the mystery kept secret
for everlasting times, (the which is now opened by the scriptures of the
prophets, after the eternal Gods commandment, to the obeynge of faith,)
known in all nacyons, unto Roma. ^1. d
the only wise God through Jesus Christ, unto whom be honor and glory for ever.
Amen.

The end of the Epistle of Paul the Apostle to the Romans.
The first Epistle of the Apostle Paul to the the Corinthians.
The first Chapter.
Paul called an Apostle Actu. 1^. ^
Sosthenes, unto the congregation that is at Corinthus, Ioh. 17. c Hebr. 9. c
being sanctified in Christ Jesus, called saints, with al them that call upon
the name of our LORD Jesus Christ in every place of theyrs and ours, 2.
Cori. 1. ^
grace be unto you and peace from God our father, and the LORD Jesus Christ.
I thank my God always for you, for ye grace of God that is given you in Christ
Jesus, that in all things ye are made rych in him, in every word and in every
knowledge, as the witness of Christ is stablyshed in you: so that nothing do
want unto you in any grace, waiting for the appearing of our LORD Jesus
Christ, the which also shall stablysh you without fault until the end, in the
day of the coming of our LORD Jesus Christ. Number. 23. c 2. Cor. 10. b ^.
Tessa. 5. c
God is faithful, by whom ye are called unto the fellowshippe of his son
Roma. 12. c
that ye all speak one thing, and that there be in you no divisions: but be ye
perfect in one meaning and in one sentence. For it is showed me of you my
brethren by them that are of Chloes [householde,] that there are stryfes among
you. But of this I speak, that every one of you says: I truly ame of Paul,
and I of Actu. 18. c 1. Cor. 3. a and.16. b
Apollo, but I of Cephas, but I of Christ. Is Christ divided? Was Paul
crucified for you? or were ye baptized in the name of Paul? I thank my God
that I have baptized none of you save Actu. 18. a
Crispus and To. 16. c
Gaius, lest any man say, ye were baptized in my name. I have baptized also
the house of ^. Cor. 16. c
Stephana. Else wot I not whether I have baptized any other of you. For Christ
sent me not to baptyse, but to preach, not in the wisdom of words, that
the cross Roma. 1. b
but unto them that are saved, that is, unto us, it is the power of God. For it
is written: Esaias. 29. c
I will destroy the wysedom of the wise, and the understanding of the
prudente shall I refuse. Esaias. 3^. ^
Where is the wise? where is the scribe? where is the disputer of this world?
Has not God made the wisdom of this world foolysh? For because the world
by ye wisdom of God did not know God, it has pleased God to save the
beleuynge by the foolyshnesse of the preaching. Math. 1^. d Luce* 11. c Ioh.
2. c and.6. d
For the Jews also require tokens, and the Greeks seek wisdom: but we
preach Christ the crucified: unto the Jews truly an offendicle, but unto the
Heythen a foolyshnesse. But unto the called Jews and Greeks Christ the power
of God, and Collos. 2. a
the wisdom of God. For what foolysh is of God Johan. 7. ^
not many wise after the flesh, not many mighty, not many nobles: but the
things of the world that are foolyshe has God chosen, that he may confound
the wise: and the weak things of ye world has God chosen, that he may
confound the strong: and the vile and despised things of the world has God
chosen, Osee. 2. c
and those things that are not [worth,] that he should destroy those things
that are [worth,] that all flesh rejoice not in his syghte. Of the same ye are
in Christ Jesus, which is become unto us Ephesians. 1. c
wisdom, Iere. 23. b
and righteousness, and Ioh. 7. c
hallowynge, and redemption, that (as it is written) Esaias. 6^. c Iere. 9. d 2.
Cori. 11. a
He that rejoices, let him rejoice in the LORD.

The.ii. Chapter.
1. Tessa. 1. a
and my word and my preaching was not in persuadynge words of man's wisdom,
but in declarynge of sprete and power, that your faith be not in the wisdom
of men, but in ye power of God. And we speak wisdom among them that are
perfect: but not the wisdom of this world, nor of ye rulers of this world,
which ^. Cori. 15 c
go to naught but we speak the wisdom of God in mystery, which is hyd, the
which God has predestinate unto our praise before the world, the which
Math. 11. ^
none of the rulers of this world has known. Ioha^. 15. c and. 16. a Actu.
13. c
For if they had known it, they should never have crucified the LORD of
glory. But as it is written: That Esaias. 64. a
the eye has not seen, nor the ear has herd, nor yet is gone up into the
heart of man, what things god has prepared unto Roma. 8. b
For the spret searches al things, even the depenesses of God also. For who
is he of men that knows what belong unto man, save ye spret of man that is
in him? Even so also what things belo^ge unto God has noman known, save ye
sprete of God. But we have not received ye sprete of this world, but the
sprete that is of God, that we may know what things are given us of God: the
which things also we speak, not in conning words of man's wisdom, but in
the doctrine of ye spret, comparynge spiritual things to spiritual. The
natural man perceaueth not those things that belong to the sprete of God,
for it is foolyshnesse unto him, and he can not understand it: for it is
examined spiritually. Pro. 2^. ^
But ye spiritual judges all things, and himself is judged of noman. As it
is written: Sap. 9 b Es^. 4^. b Romans 11. d
For who has known the mind of the LORD? or who has instruct him? But we
have the mind of Christ.

The.iii. Chapter.
ANd I brethren could not Heb. 5. ^
I gave you milk to drink as unto babes in Christ, not meat: for ye could
not yet, another truly can ye now: for ye are yet carnal. Gala. 5. ^
Seeing there is among you enuyenge and strife, are ye not carnal, and walk
after man? For when any man says: 1. Cor. 1. b
I truly am of Paul, but another: I am of Apollo, are not ye me^? What is
Apollo therefore? But what is Paul? His ministers whom ye have believed, and
unto every one as God has given. I have planted, Apollo has watered, Ioha^.
6. g Actu. 2. ^
but god has given ye increace. Therefore, another he that planteth is ought,
nor he ye waters, but God that gives the increace. And he that planteth, and
he that waters are one. But every one shall receive his own reward,
according to his work. For we are Gods helpers, ye are Gods husba^dry, Ephesians.
2. c
ye are Gods building. Math. 16 c
For noma^ can lay another fundamente than it that is laid, which is Christ
Jesus. But if any man build upon this fundamente gold, silver, precious
stones, wood hey, stubble, every man's work shall be manifest: Esa. 28. c
For the day of the LORD shall declare it. For it shall be disclosed in fire,
and every man's work what it be shall 1. Petri. 1 b and. 4. d
the fire declare. If any man's work yt he has builded upon it, do abide, he
shall receive reward: If any man's work shall burn, he shall suffer harm, but
he shall be safe: nevertheless so as through fire. ^. Cor. 6. c ^. Cori. 6. c
Hebre. 3. a
Know ye not that ye are the temple of God, and ye sprete of God dwells in
you. But if any do defyle the temple of God, God shall destroy him: For the
temple of God Prove. 3. c
Let noman myscary you. If any man among you seems to be wise, let him become
a fool in this world, that he may be wise. For Roma. 1. c
the wisdom of this world is foolyshnesse with God. For it is written: Job.
5 b
I will take the wise in their sutteltye. And again. Psa. 93. b
The LORD knows the thoughts of the wise, that they are vain. Let noman
therefore rejoice in men. For all things are yours, whether it be Paul,
whether it be Apollo, whether it be Cephas, whether it be the world, wheher it
be life, whether it be death, whether they be things present, or things to
come. Al things truly are yours but ye are Christ's, and Christ gods.

The.iiii. Chapter.
LEt man so esteem us, as 2. Cori. 6. a
ministers of Christ, and disposers of the Deuteronomy. 29. d
secrets of God. Here is it now required among the disposers that any be
found Iere. 23. ^ Luce. ^2. ^ 1. Pet^. 4. d
faithful. But I count it for ye leest thing that I be judged of you or of
man's day: but another do I judge myself. For I know my self gylty of
nothing, Johan. 9. a
but in that am I not justified. He that judges me, it is the LORD. Judge not
therefore before the time, until ye LORD come, which also shall lyghten ye hyd
things of darkness, and shall make manifest the counsels of ye hearts: and
tha^ shall every one have praise of God. But these things brethren Jacob. 1. a
But what have thou yt thou have not received? And if thou have received it,
what do thou boaste as though you had not received it? Now be ye
satisfied, now be ye made rich, ye raygne without us, and would God ye did
raygne, that we also might raygne with you. For I suppose that God has
declared us the last apostles, Psalm. 43. c Roma. 8. e
as appointed to death: because we are become a gasynge stock unto the world,
and angels, and men: We fools for Christ's sake, but ye wise in Christ: We
weak, but ye strong: Ye of reputacion, but we of no reputacion. Until this
hour we both honger, and thyrste, and are naked, and are buffetted, and are
vnsatled, and Actu. 18. a and.20. c
labor workynge with our hands: we are cursed, Rom* 12. b
and bless: we are persecuted, and suffer: we are euel spoken of, and we pray:
we are become as the outswypynges of the Ga^^. 4. a Jacob. 1. b
begotten you in Christ Jesus by the Gospel. I pray you therefore, be ye 1.
Cori. 11. a Philip. 3. c
followers of me, as I am of Christ. Therefore have I sent Timothe unto you
which is my most beloved son, and faithful in the LORD, which shall put
you in remembrance of my ways that are in Christ Jesus, as I teach every
where in every congregation. Some are pufte up, as though I be not coming
unto you. But I will come shortly, Pro. 20. d Iere. 10. d Jacob. 4. b
if God will, and will know not the word of the^ that are puffed up, but the
power. For ye kingdom of God is not in word but in power. What will ye? shall
I come unto you with a rod, or with love, and sprete of meekness.

The.v. Chapter.
There is wholly herd among Leuit. 18. a
that one have his fathers wife. And ye be pufte up, and have not rather had
sorrow, that he were taken away from the myddest of you that has done ye
deed. Collo. 2. a
I truly being absent in body, but present in sprete have judged already as
present, you being gathered and my sprete, with the power of our LORD Jesus
Christ, Math. 18. b 1. Tim. 1. c
to betake him that has so done unto Satanas, to the distruccion of the
flesh, that the sprete be safe in ye day of our LORD Jesus Christ. Your Gala.
5. a
Know ye not that a little leven sowreth the whole lompe of dowe. Pourge
therefore the old leven, that ye may be a new dowe, as ye be vnleue^ded
bread. For Christ our Esaias. 53. b Ioha^. 1. c
Easterla^be is offered. Let us therefore Exo. 12. ^
be merry not in the old leven, nor in the leue^ of maliciousness and
wickedness, but in the vnleuended breades of sincerenesse and truth. I wrote
unto you in a letter: Eccl^. ^5. a
that ye should not meddle with the whoremongers, truly not the whoremongers of
this world or covetous, or extorcioners or seruers of Idols, orels ought ye to
have gone out of this world. 2. Tessa. 3* a
But now have I written unto you, not to meddle. If he that is called a brother
among you is a whoremonger, or covetous, or a worshipper of Idols, or a rayler,
or a dro^karde, or an extorcioner, Iere. 16. a Dani. 1. b.
with such one to take no meat. For what is it unto me to judge of them that
are without? Do not ye judge of them that are within? For them that are
without shall God judge. Deuteronomy. 15. a
Have away the evil from among yourselues.

The.vi. Chapter.
Math. 12. d and.19. d
Know ye not that saints shall judge ye world? And if the world shall be
judged of you, ye are unworthy that ye be judged of the leest. Know ye not
that we shall judge the angels? How much more worldly matters? If ye shall
have therefore worldly judgments, the more vyler that are in the
congregation, these ordyne to judge. I say it to your shame. Is there no wise
man among you yt be able to judge between his brother? But ye brother stryueth
with his brother in judgment, and Math. 5. e
Why do not ye rather suffer wrong? But ye do wrong and begyle, and that unto
the brethren. Know ye not that the wicked shall not possess the kingdom of
God? Err not. Gala. 5. c Ephesians. 5. a
Another the whoremongers, nor the worshippers of Idols, nor the aduouterous,
nor the weaklynges, nor the abusers of themselves with mankind, nor thieves,
nor the covetous, nor the dronkardes, nor the cursed speakers, nor extorcioners
the extorcioners shall possess the kingdom of God. And these things truly
have ye been, but ye are washen, but ye are sanctified, but ye are justified in
the name of our LORD Jesus Christ, and in the sprete of our God. All
things Eccli. ^7. d 1. Cori. 10. c
but al things are not expedient. All things are leafull unto me, but I will
be brought under nomans power. The meat unto the belly, and the belly for
meats: but God shall destroy this and those. But the body not unto
fornicacion, but unto the LORD? and ye LORD unto the body. But Roma. 8. ^
God has both raised the LORD by his power, and shall raise us also. Or know
ye not that your bodies are members of Christ? Shall I than taking away the
members of Christ make them the members of an harlotte? That be far. Know
ye not that he that cleueth unto an harlotte, becomes one body? For they
Genes. 2. ^
(says he) shall be two in one flesh. But he that cleueth unto the LORD, is
one sprete. Fly fornicacion. For all sin what soever a man does, is without
the body: but he that commytteth whoredom, synneth in his body. 1. Cori. ^.
b 2. Cor. 6. c
Or know ye not that your members are the temple of the holy ghost, that is
in you, whom ye have of God, and ye are not your own? 1. Cor. ^. ^ 1. Petri.
1. ^
For ye are boughte with a great price. Glorifye and bear God in your body.

The.vii. Chapter.
Tob. 6. d and. 8 a Joel. 2. c
Wythdrawe not yourselues from each other, without happily it be of consent for
a time, that ye may give you to prayer: and return again to the same, lest
Satan tempte you for your inco^tinency. But this I say according to favor,
not after a commandment. Actu. 26. c
For I would have you all to be as myself: but every one has his own gift of
God, ye one truly thus, ye other so. But I say unto the not married and
wedowes, it is good unto the^ if they shall so abide, as I also. ^. Tim. 5. b
If so be they do not absteyne themselves, let them mary: for it is better to
mary, Math. 5. d and. 19. a
the woman not to go away from the man. If she go away, to abide unmarried, or
to be reconciled unto her husband. And let not the man leave his wife. As for
unto the rest say I, not the LORD: If any brother have an unfaithful wife,
and the same agrees to dwell with him, let him not leave the same. And if any
woman have an unfaithful man, and the same consents to dwell with her, let
her not leave the man: for the unfaithful man is sa^ctifyed through the
faithful woman, and the unfaithful woman is sanctified through the faithful
man, or else were your children unclean, but now they are holy. If the
unfaithful goes away, let him go away: for a brother or sister is not
bound in such cases. But God has called us in peace. 1. Pet. 3. a
For whence know thou o woman, whether thou shall save the man? Or whence
know thou o man, whether thou shalt save the woman? save as the LORD has
distributed unto every man. As Ephe. 4. a
God has called every man, so let him walk, and so I teach in all
congregacions. Is any man called 1. Timo. 6. a
Art thou called a servant? care not: but and if thou may be fre, use it
rather. For whosoever is called a seruau^te in the LORD, he is a fre man of ye
LORD. Likewise he that is called being fre, is the servant of Christ. 1.
Cor. 6. c 1. Pet. 1. c
Ye ar bought with a dear price, become not the servants of men. Every one
therefore brethren where in he is called, let him abide in the same with God.
But of the vir: gines I have no commandment of the LORD, nevertheless I
give counsel, as having optayned mercy of the LORD, that I be faithful. I
suppose it to be good for the present necessite, for it is good for a man so
to be. Art thou bound to a wife? seek not lowsynge. Art thou lowse from a
wife? seek not a wife. But if thou take a wife, thou haste not sinned. And if a
virgyne mary, she has not sinned: Nevertheless such shall have trouble of
the flesh. But I favor you. Psalm. 89. a 2. Petri. 3. a
the time is short. It remains, that they also that have wives, be as not
having: and they that weep, as not weeping: and they that rejoice, as not
reioycynge: and they that bye, as not possessynge: and they that use this
world, as though they used it not: for Esa. 4^ a 1. Ioh. 2. c
the fashion of this world passes away. Mat. 6. c Luce. 12. c
But I would have you to be without carfulness. 1. Tim. 5. a
He that is without a wife, is careful for the things that be the LORDS,
how he may please God. But he that is with a wife is careful of the things
that be of the world, how he may please his wife, and is divided. And a
woman that is unmarried and a virgin, cares for ye things that are the
LORDS, that she be holy both body and sprete. But she that is married, cares
for the not that I should cast a snare on you, but because of it that is
honest, and that may give a lyberte to pray ye LORD without impediment. But
if any man think him to be estymed blameable for his virgin, because that she
is ouergrowen, and it must so be done: let him do what he will, he synneth
not, if he mary her. For he that being sure in his heart has so purposed,
having no need, but having power of his will, and have determined that in his
heart [namely] to keep his virgin, he does well. Therefore both he that coupleth
his virgyne in marriage, does well: and he that joins her not does better.
Roma. 7. a
The woman is bound to the law as long as her husband lives If so be that
her husband do sleep, she is fre, let her marye whom she will, only in the
LORD. But she shall be more happyer after my counsel, if she shall continue so.
I suppose that I have the sprete of God also.

The.viii. Chapter.
But of those things that Actu. 15. d
offered up unto Idols Rom^ 14. b
we know ye we have al knowledge. Knowledge puffs up, but love edifyeth. But
he yt thinks him to know ought, he has not yet known how it behooves him to
know. But he that leueth God, the same is known of him. And as for the meats
yt be offered up unto Idols, we know that 1. Cori. 10. c
the Idol is nothing in the world, Deuteronomy. 4. f and. 6. b Esaias. 4.4. b
and ye there is no God save one. For though there be yt are estimed gods, either
in heaven, Psalm. 18. a
or in earth (for there are many gods, and many lords,) yet have we but Ephesians.
4. a
one God the father, Romans 11. d
of whom are all things, and we in him: and one LORD Jesus Christ, by whom 1.
Cor. 10. d.
ye conscience of an Idol hitherto eat it as a thing offered unto an Idol,
and their conscience where as it is weak, is defiled. But meat does not
forther us unto God. For another shall we have abundaunce, if we eat: another
shall we want, if we eat not. But beware lest happily this your lyberte
become a stomblynge block unto the weak. For if some man shall se him that
has knowledge, sit eating of the Idols [meate,] shall not his conscience when
it is weak, be stablyshed to eat Idols offerynges? and the weak brother for
whom Christ dyed shall peryshe by thy conscience. But ye so synnynge against
the brethren and smiting their weak consciences, ye sin against Christ.
Wherefore Roma. 14. c
if meat offend my brother, I will never eat flesh, lest I offe^de my
brother.

The.ix. Chapter.
Actu. 9. a
not I fre? Am not I an Apostle? 1. cor. 11. b
Have not I seen Jesus Christ our LORD? Are not ye my workemanshippe in the
LORD? And though I am not an Apostle unto other, yet am I unto you: for ye are
ye seal of mine Apostleship in ye LORD. My defense by them that axe at me, is
this: Have not we power to eat and drink? Have we not power to lead about a
woman Phili. 4. a
sister, as also the other Apostles and brethren of the LORD, and Math. 8. b
Luc. 4. d
Cephas? Or have I only and Barnabas not power to do that? Who does ever
warrefare upon his own wages? Who does pla^te a vine, and eats not of his
fruit? Who fedeth a flock and eats not of the milk of the flock? Say I
these things after Deu. 25. a 1. Timo. 5. c
Thou shalt not mosell the mouth unto the ox, treading out the corn. Does
God care for ye oxen? Does he not verily say it for our sakes? For they are
written for our sakes, because ye he that eareth, must ear upon hope: and he
yt treads out the corn, upon hope to obtain fruit. Roma. 15. ^* Gala. 6. a
If we have sowe^ unto you spiritual things, is it a great thing if we do
reap your carnal things? If other are partakers of your power, why not
rather we: 2. Cor. 11. ^
But we have not used this power, but we suffer all things, lest we give any
hynderau^ce unto the Gospel of Christ. Know ye not yt they that serve in the
temple, eat of the things that are of the temple? and they that serve the
altar, are partakers of the altar? Math. 10. ^
Even so has ye LORD ordyned unto them yt serve the Gospel, to live of the
Gospel. Actu. 20. c 1. Tessa. 2. b 2. Tessa. ^. ^
But I have used none of the things. Nevertheless I have not written these
things that they be so done in me: for it is rather better for me to dye, than
that any man should make my reioycynge void. For though I shall preach, it is
no praise to me: for need lies upon me. Woe unto me, if I shall not preach. For
if I do it wyllyng, I have reward: but if [I do it] against my will, the
disposynge is committed unto me. What is than my reward? [namely] that I
preaching the Gospel, do utter the Gospel freely, that I do not mysuse my
power in the Gospel. Actu. 22. c
For when I was fre from all things, I have made me the servant of all, that
I might win the more. Actu. 16. a 18. b. 21. c and.24. b
And I am become unto the Jews as a Jew, that I might win the Jews: Unto
them that are under the law, as though I were under the law, (wha^ yet I was
not under ye law,) that I might win them that were under the law: Gala. 2. a
Unto the^ that were without law, as though I were without law, (wha^ yet I
was not without ye law of God, but was in Christ's law,) that I might win
them yt were without law. I am become weak unto the weak, that I might win the weak. ^. Cori. 10. d
I am become of al fashions unto every one, yt I might save all me^. But I do
al things because of the Gospel, that I may be partaker of it. Know ye not
yt they that run in a course, they truly do all run, but one receaueth ye
reward? Run ye so that ye may obtain. But every one that proves maystry
abstayneth from all things: and they truly, that they may receive a
corruptible crown, but we 2. Tim. 4. b ^. Petr. 5. a
an vncorrupped. I therefore do run so, not as at an uncertain thing: I fight
so, not as beatynge the air: but I chastyse my body, and bring it in
subieccion, lest when I have preached unto other, I myself become a castawaye.

The.x. Chapter.
BRethren, I would not you Exodi. 13. d
that our fathers were all under a cloud, Exodus 14. ^
and they all passed through the sea, and they all were baptized by Moses in the
cloud and in the sea, and they al Exodi. 16. c

16. c
rock followynge the^, and the rock was Christ.) But in many of them had God
no pleasure, Number. 14. ^
for they were overthrown in ye deserte. But these things happened in a
figure unto us, that we should not be lustynge of evil things, as they also
lusted. Another become ye worshippers of Idols, as some of them, as it is
written: Exodi. ^2. b
The people did sit down to eat and to drink, and rose up to play. Another
let us committee whoredom, Number. 25. a Psalm. 105. a
as some of the^ committed whoredom, and there fell on one day three and twenty
thousand. Another let us tempte Christ, Number. 21. a
as some of them tempted, and peryshed of the serpents. Another do ye murmr,
Number. 11. ^
as some of them did murmr, and peryshed of the destroyer. But all these
happened unto stand, beware lest he fall. Let no te^ptacion take hold upon
you, save it that follows the nature of man. 1. Cor. 1. a 1. Tessa. 5. c
But God is faithful, ^. Pet. 2. b
which shall not suffer you to be tempted above it that ye be able, but shall
even with the temptacio^ make a way to come forth, that ye may suffer it.
Wherefore ye most beloved unto me, fly from the worshippynge of Idols. I
speak as unto wise men, judge ye your selves what I say. The cup of
thankesgeuynge the which we bless, is it not the communicacyon of the blood
of Christ? And ye bread yt we break, is it not the partakynge of the body of
the LORD? For we many are one bread and one body, all we truly that take
part of one 1. Cori. 8. a
Will I say that ye thing offered up unto Idols be ought? or that the Idol be
ought? But what the Heythen offer, they offer it unto deuels, and not unto God
But I will not have you to become partakers of deuels. Ye can not drink the
cup of the LORD, and the cup of the deuels: ye can not be partakers of the
table of the LORD and of ye table of deuels. Or will we provoke ye LORD? Are we
stronger tha^ he? Eccli^. 37. d 1. Cor. 6. c
Al things are leaful unto me, but all things are not expedient: al things
are leafull unto me, but all things edifye not. ^. Cori. 13. a
Let noma^ seek that his is, but yt is another ma^s. Al thing that is sold in
the shambles do ye eat, not axynge, because of ye conscience. Psalm. 32. a
The LORDS is the earth and his fullness. If any of ye infydels byddeth you to
supper, and ye will go, all that is set before you, eat of it, not axynge,
because of the conscience. But if any man shall say: That is 1. Cori. 8. b
the conscience, not thine, but of the other. For what is my lyberte judged of
another man's conscience? 1. Tim. 4. a
If I take part with thanks, why I am euel spoken of for that wherefore I give
thanks? Therefore, Collos. 2. b
whether ye eat, whether ye drink, or do ought else, do all things to the
glory of God. Be without offendicle unto the Jews and Gentyles, and the
congregation of God: 1. Cori. 9. d
Even as I also please all men in all things, not sekyng it that is profitable
unto me but that [is profitable] unto many, that they may be saved.

The.xi. Chapter.
BE 1. Cori. 4. ^
ye my followers, as I Ephe. 5. c
the head of the woman is the man: but the head of Christ is God. Every man
prayenge or prophecyenge, the head being covered, does shame his head. But
every woman prayeng or prophecyeng, the head not being covered, shameth her
head: for it is all one as though she were shaven. For if the woman is not
covered, let her here be cut of. Deuteronomy. 22. a 1. Cori. 14. c
But if it is uncomely for a woman to have the here cut of, or to be shaven,
let her cover her head, The man truly ought not to cover his head, Ephesians. 4. c
for he is the image and glory of God, but the woman is the glory of the man.
Genesis 2. d
For the man is not of the woman, but the woman of the man. For the man was not
created for the woman, but the woman ^. Tim. 6. c
But if any seems to be contencious, we have not such costume, another the
congregation of God. But this I command not praysyng, that ye come together
not for better, but for worse. For first I hear that as ye come together into
the congregation, that there are divisions, and I believe it partly. Math. 18. a
^. Ioha^. 2. c
For there must also be sects among you, that they yt are proved, become
manifest the LORDS supper: for every one takes his own supper before him to
eat, and the one truly has honger but the other is drunk. Have ye not
houses to eat and drink in? Or despise ye the congregation of God, and shame
the^ that have not? What shall I say unto you? In this do I not praise you. For
I have received of the LORD that, which I have also delivered unto you, Math.
26. c Marc. 1^. c Luce. 22. b
that ye LORD Jesus in what night he was betrayed, he took ye bread, and

53. a
yt shall be delivered for you: do this in the remembrance of me. Likewise also
ye cup after yt he had supped, saying: This cup is ye new testament in my
blood this do as often as ye shall drink it in my remembrance. For as often as ye
shall eat this bread, and drink of the cup, ^. P^tr. ^. b
ye shall show ye death of the LORD, until Actu. ^. b
he come. Therefore whosoever shall eat the flesh and 2. Cori. 13. b
But let a man examine himself, and let him so eat of that bread, and drink

drynketh judgment unto him self, making no difference of the body of the
LORD. Therefore are there many weak and feeble among you, and many do sleep.
Eccli. ^8. ^
If we did examine oureselues, verelye we should not be judged. But when we are
judged, we are chastened of the LORD, that we be not Johan. 2. c
damned with this world. Therefore my brethren, wha^ ye come together to eat,
tarry one for another. If any man does honger, let him eat at home, that ye
come not together unto judgment. But as for other things shall I set in order
wha^ I shall come.

The.xii. Chapter.
Marc. 9. d
that noman speaking by the sprete of God does defye Jesus. And noman can say
the LORD Jesus, save by the holy ghost. Roma. 12. a
There are verily diversities of gifts, but one sprete. And there are
diversities of offices, but one LORD. And there are diversities of operacions,
Ioh. 5 b
but one God, that works al things in all. Ephesians. 4. a
Unto every man is declaryng of ye sprete given to profit: unto the one truly
is given by the sprete ye vtterau^ce of wisdom: and unto another after the
same sprete [is geuen] the vtteraunce of knowledge: unto another faith in ye
same sprete: unto another the grace of healynges in the same sprete: unto
another ye workynge of miracles: unto another prophecy: unto another ^. Ioh. 4.
a
discernynge of spretes: unto another the diversities of tunges: unto another
interpretacion of speches. But all these does the one Roma. 12. a
For as the body is one, Ephe. 4. b
and has many me^bres, but all the members of the body though they are many,
yet are one body, even so Christ also. For by one sprete are we all baptized in
one body, whether we be Jews or Gentyls, whether we be bondmen or fre: and
Esaias. 55. a Ioha^. 7. d
have al drunk of one sprete. For the body also is not one member, but many.
If the foot shall say: I am not the hand, I am not of the body, is it
therefore not of the body? And if the ear shall say: I am not of the eye, I am
not of the body, is it therefore not of ye body? If all ye body is an eye, where
is the hearing? If it be al hearing, where is smellyng? But now has God set
ye me^bres in the body, every one of the^ as it has pleased him. If al ye
members were one, where were the body? Now truly are there many members, but
one body. The eye can not say unto the either if one membre rejoices, all the
members rejoice with it. But ye are the body of Christ, and members of the
membre. And some truly has God ordined in the congregation: first Math. 10. a
Luce. 9. a Ephesians. 4. a
Apostles, secondarly prophets, thyrdly Actu. 13. a
teachers, than powers, thence forth the graces of healynge, helpynges,
gouernau^ces, kinds of speches, interpretacions of sayenges. Are they all
Apostles? Are they all prophets? are they all teachers? are they al powers?
have they all the grace of healynges? Do they all speak with tunges? do they
all interpret? But covet ye ye best gifts. And yet I show you a more
excellent way.

The.xiii. Chapter.
Math. 7. b
And if I shall have prophecye, and shall know all mysteryes, and all
knowledge, and if I shall have al faith, insomuch Luce. 17. ^
that I shall remove hills, but shall have no charity, I am nothing. And if I
shall distribute all my goods for meats unto the poor, and if I shall give my
body, so that I shall burn, but shall have no charity, it profyteth me
nothing. Love is paciente, she is courteous, love does not envy, she does not
wyckedly, she is not pufte up, she is not covetous of honor, Phili. 2. b
she seeks not the things that be her own, she is not provoked to anger, she
thinks not evil, she rejoices not over wickedness, but rereioyceth with the
truth, she suffers al things, she believes al things, she hops al things
she bears up al things. Love never falls away, whether prophecyes shall be
voyded, whether ye tu^ges shall cease, whether knowledge shall be destroyed. For
of part we know, and of part we prophecy But wha^ it yt is perfect shall come,
than shall it that is of part be voyded. When I was a child, I spoke as a
child, I understood as a child, I thought as a child. But when I was become a
man, I did void the things that belonged to a child. We se now in a glass
[euen] in a dark speaking, but tha^ face to face I know now of a part, but
tha^ shall I know, as I also am known. Now abide faith, hope, love, these
three: but the greater of these is love.

The.xiiii. Chapter.
FOllow upon love, couete brethren, if I shall come unto you speaking with
tunges, what shall I profit you, without I shall speak unto you either by
reuelacio^, or by knowledge, or by prophecy, or by doctrine? thankest well, but
the other is not edifyed. I thank God yt I speak with the tunge of you all.
Even so in ye congregation would I lever speak five words with mine
understanding, that I may teach other also, tha^ ten thousand of words with
the tu^ge. Ephe. 4. a
Brethren, become not children in your understandings, but in wickedness be
children, but be perfect in vndersta^dynges. For it is written in the law:
Esaias. 28. b
that with other tu^ges, and with other lyppes will I speak unto this people,
and they shall not so hear me another, says ye LORD. Actu. 2. b
Therefore are tunges for a token, not unto the faithful, but unfaithful. But
prophecyes not unto ye unfaithful, but let him speak to himself and god. As
for the prophets, let two or three speak, and 1. Ioha^. 4. a
let the other judge. If so be that it is showed by reuelacion unto some other
sitting, let ye first hold his peace. For ye may al prophecye by one, yt al
may learn, and all Roma. 15. d
but of peace, as I teach in all the congregacions of the saints. 1. Cori. 11.
a 1. Tim. 2. b
Let the women keep silence in ye co^gregacions: for it is not permytted unto
them to speak, but to be subject, Genes. ^. c
as the law also says. But if they will learn ought, let them axe at their
husbands at home: For it is vnco^ly unto a woman to speak in the
congregation. Is the word of God come forth from you? Or is it come upon you
only? If any man seems to be a prophet, or spiritual, let him know what
things I do write unto you, that they be the commandments of ye LORD. But
if any man knows it not, he shall not be known. Therefore brethren covet to
prophecye, and forbid not to speak with tunges. But Collo. 2. ^
let al things be done honestly and after an order among you.

do you wete brethren ye gospel, yt which I have preached unto you, yt which ye

For I am the leest of the Apostles, which am not worthy to be called an

for I have persecuted the congregation of God. But by the grace of If we are

at Ephesus, what profyteth it me, if the dead do not rise again? Esaias. 22. b

Let us eat and drink, for tomorowe shall we dye. Be not deceived. Evil
co^municacio^s corruppe good manners. Mena^de^*
Awaken ryghtfully and sin not: for some are ignorant of God. I speak it
for a shame unto you. But some body will say: How do the dead rise again?
And with what body shall they come? Thou fool, Ioha. 12. c
that which thou sowest is not quickened, without it first do dye. And what
sowest thou? Thou sowest not the body yt shall be, but a bare corn, namely of
wheat or any of ye other. But God gives it a body as he will, and unto every
one of the seeds Math. 13. ^
There is one clearness of the Son, another of the Moon, and another
clearenesse of the stars. For one star differreth from another in
clearness: and even so ye resurreccion from the dead. It is sown in
corrupcion, it shall rise in vncorrupcion. It is sowe^ in vileness, it shall
rise in glory. It is sown in weakness, it shall rise in power. It is sown a
natural body, it shall rise a spiritual. If there is a natural body, there is a
spiritual also, as it is written: Genesis 2. b
The first Adam was made a living soul, the last Adam into a quyckenynge
sprete. But it that is spiritual is not first, but it that is natural, and
than it that is spiritual. The first man of the earth, is earthy: the second
man of the heaven, heavenly. As ye earthy is, such are the earthy also: and as
the heavenly is, such are the heavenly also. Therefore, as we have boren the
image of the earthy, so let us also bear the image of the heavenly. But this I
say brethren, because flesh and blood can not possess ye kingdom of God:
another shall corrupcion 1. Tess. 4. c
We shall all sleep in deed, but we shall not all Phil. 3. c
be changed in a momente, in the twynclynge of an eye, at the last trompe. For
the trompe shall blow, and the dead shall rise Roma. 8. a Col. 3 a Phili. 3.
c 1. Ioh. 3. a
incorrupt, and we shall be changed. For this corruptible must put on
vncorrupcion, and this mortal must put on immortalite. But wha^ this mortal
shall have put on immortalite, than shall the saying that is written befall:
Esaias. 25. b
Death is swalowed up in ye victory. Where is thy victory death? Osee. 13. c
Heb. 2. a
Death where is thy stynge? But the stynge of death is sin, and the power of
sin is the law. But thanks be unto God, ^. Ioha^. 5. a
which has given us the victory through our LORD Jesus Christ. Therefore my
beloved brethren, be steadfast and immovable, being always rych in every work
of the LORD, knowing yt your labor is not in vain in the LORD.

The.xvi. Chapter.
Roma. 15. d 1. Cori. 8. a and.9. a
gatherynges yt are made for ye saints, as I have ordined in ye co^gregacio^s

letters, those shall I send to carry your grace unto Jerusalem. If so be it

and many adversaries. Act. 19. c

was wantinge unto you, that have they supplied: for they have refreshed my
sprete and yours. Know them therefore that are such. All the congregacions of
