is according to ye gospel of the glory of the blessed God, which is
committed unto me. I thank him that has comforted me in Christ Jesus our
LORD, because he has counted me faithful, setting me in the office, which
was first a blasphemer and Act. 9. a. Gal. 1. a.
persecuter, and a doer of iniurye, but I have optayned the mercy of God, for I
did it ignorauntly in mysbelefe. But the grace of our LORD was plenteous with
the faith and love, which is in Christ Jesus. This saying is true, and by all
means Math. 9. b Ioh. 3. c.
That Christ Jesus did come into this world to save sinners, whereof I am the
chief. But I have optayned mercy therefore, [namely:] that in me Christ Jesus
should show all patience, to the informacio^ of them, that shall believe him
unto life everlasting. But unto the everlasting king immortal, Coll. 1. b
invisible, the only God, be honor and glory for ever and ever. Amen. This
commandment do I commytte unto the my son Timothe, according to the
prophecyes in the in times past, that thou fight in them a good fight, having
faith and a good conscience, the which some puttyng away, they have suffered
shipwrake concerning faith: of the which is ^. Tim. 2. b
Hymeneus and 2. tim. 4* b
Alexander, 1. Cor. 5. a
the which I have delivered unto Satanas, yt they learn not to blaspheme.

The.iii. Chapter.
This is a faithful word: Leuit. 21. b Eze. 44. d Tit. 1. b
ye husband of one wife, sobre, wise, manerlye, chaste, harberous, 2. tim. 2. c
a teacher, no dro^karde, no fyghter, but still, no stryuer, not covetous, but
a ruler of his house well, having children obediente with all chastity. But if
any can not rule his own house, how shall he be diligente in the congregation
of God? no new scolar, lest he being heaued up into pride, do fall into the
judgment of the deuell. And he must also have a good report of them that are
without, that he do not fall into rebuke and Act. 6. a.
The ministers must likewise be chaste, not dubble tunged, not given to much
wine, not followynge fylthy lucre, having the mystery of faith in a pure
conscience. And let these also be proved first, and let the^ so ministre,
having no blame. The weme^ likewise chaste, not backbytynge, sobre, faithful
in all things. Let the ministers be the husbands of one wife, which govern
their children well, and their houses. Mat. 13 b. and.25. b. c.
For they that shall ministre well, they shall get themselves a good degree, and
much boldness in ye faith which is in Christ Jesus. These things do I write
unto the my son Timothe, hoping me to come unto the shortly: but if I shall
tarry long, that thou may know how thou must be co^uersau^t in the house of
God, the which is ye congregation of the living God, the stay and Math. 16. c
stablyshmente of the truth. And without nay it is a great mystery of

The.v. Chapter.
Leuit. 19. g
the younger men, as brethren: the elder women as mothers: the younger women, as

pleasures, living she is dead. And command this, [namely] that they be
unblameable Gal. 6. b.

and is worse tha^ ^. Petr. 4. b

in Christ, they will mary, having damnacio^, because they have cast away ye
first faith. Titu. 2. a
And being also idle they learn to go about from house to house: not only

need not. 1. Cor. 7. a
But I will the younger women to mary, to bring forth children, to be house
wives, to give no occasion unto the adversary to speak evil. For some are
turned back already after Satan. If any faithful has wedowes let him
ministre unto them, that ye congregation be not charged, yt they which are true
wedowes may have enough. The Elders that rule well, Deuteronomy. 25. a 1. Cori. 9. b

Mat. 10. a
labourer is worthy of his wages. Deuteronomy. 19. ^

these things without fore judgment, doing nothing leaning to ye one party.
1. Tim. 2. b
Lay not hands haistely upon any man, another be partener of other men's

often sycknesses. Some men's sins Gal. 5. ^
are manifest, going before to the judgment, and the [synnes] of some do
follow also. Likewise also are the good deeds manifest, and they that are
otherwise, can not be hid.

The end of the first Epistle of the Apostle Paul to Timothe.
The second Epistle of Paul the Apostle to Timothe.
The first Chapter.
1. Cori. 1. a Gal. 1. a
Grace and mercy and peace from God our father, and Christ Jesus our LORD. I
thank my God, Act. 22. a Philip. 3. a
whom I serve fro my for elders in a Romans 1. a
pure conscience, that without ceassynge I make mention of the in my prayers,
desiring night and day to se the, being aduysed of thy tears, that I may
be filled with joy, calling to mind that faith, which is unfeigned in the and
which dwelte first in Lois thy graundmother, and Eunice thy mother: and am
assured that in the also For the which cause I exhort the that thou do raise
again the grace of God which is in the by ye layeng on of my hands. Romans 8. b
For God has not given us the sprete of fear, but of power, and love, and of
soberness. Romans 1. b
Be not therefore ashamed of ye witness of our LORD, nor of me Ephe. 3. a
his presoner, but labor with the Gospel according to the power of God, which
Ephesians. 1. a Titum. 3. a
has delivered us, and called with an holy calling: not according to our
works, but according to his purpose and grace, which is given us in Christ
Jesus before the everlasting times. But is now made manifest by the
lightening of our saueour Jesus Christ, 1. Cor. 15. ^. Heb. 2. c
which truly has destroyed death, and has lyghtened life and vncorrupcion by
the Gospel, Roma. 1. a 1. Tim. 2. a
where unto I am ordyned a preacher, an Apostle, and teacher of the Heythen.
For the which cause also I suffer these things, but am not ashamed. For I
know who^ I have believed, and am sure that he is able to keep it that I have
committed unto him until ye day. 2. Tim. 3. b
Have 2. Tim. 4. c
Onesiphorus, for he has often refreshed me, and was not ashamed of my cheine
but wha^ he was come to Rome, Mat. 25. c
he sought me diligently and did find me. The LORD grant him to find mercy of
god in ye day. And how much he has served me at Ephesus know thou best.

The.ii. Chapter.
BE thou therefore strong Titu^. 1. ^.
ye same commytte unto faithful men, which shall be mete also to teach other.
Labor as a good souldyour of Christ Jesus. Noman warrynge unto God tangleth
himself with worldly busynesses, yt he may please him, which has allowed him.
For he also that stryueth for a maystrye, shall not be crowned, without he
strive lawfully. 1. Cor. 9. b
The labourynge husbandman must first receive of ye fruits. Mark what I say:
for God shall give the understanding in all things. Remember the LORD Jesus
Christ Romans 1. a
of the sede of David to be risen from the dead, according to my Gospel, in
the which I labor unto bands, as doing euel: but the word of God is not
bound. Act. 20 c Ephesians. 3. a Coll. 1. c
Therefore do I suffer all things for the chosens sake, that they also obtain
the salvation, which is in Christ Jesus, with heavenly glory. Romans 6. b
For if we be dead with him, we shall also live with him: Romans 8. b
If we shall have patience, we shall also raygne with him: Luc. 12. a
if we shall deny him, he shall also deny us: Nu. 23. c Romans 3. a
if we believe not, he abides faithful, he can not deny himself. Admonysh
these things, testifyeng before ye LORD. Strive not with words, for yt is
profitable for nothing, save to ye subuertynge of the hearers. Study to show
thyselfe alowable unto God, a Mat. 24. d
workma^ not being ashamed, treating ye word of God aryght. ^. Tim. 1. a 4.
a. 6. a 2. Tim. 2. c
As for unholy and vain talkynges do you eschew, for they auail much unto
ungodliness, and their word fretteth as a ca^ker: of ye which sort is ^. Tim.
1. c
Hymeneus and Philetus, which are fallen away from the truth, saying the
resurreccion to be past already, and have overthrown ye faith of some. But the

name of the LORD, departs from vvyckednesse. Romans 9. c

apt to teach paciente, Gala. 6. a
with softness rebukyng them yt wythsta^de the truth, if God at any time will

The.iii. Chapter.
But be sure of this, yt 1. Tim. 4. a 2. Petri. 3. a Jude. 1. c
in ye truly a shine of Godliness, but denyenge the power of it: And eschew
them. Titum. 1. c
For of them are they that go through from house to house, and lead ye woman
lade^ with sins captive, which are led with su^dery lusts, ever learning, and
never attaynynge unto ye knowledge of the truth. Exodus 7. b
But as Iamnes and Mambres wythstode Moses, even so do they also resyste the
truth, men being corrupt of mind, lewd concerning faith, but farther shall
they not profit: for their folly shall be manifest unto all me^, as Act. 13. c
and.14. a 2. Cor. 1. b
at Antioche, Iconium, Lystris, what manner of persecucions I have suffered: and
out of the^ all has the LORD delivered me. Psalm. 33. c Eccli. 2. a
And all they that will live Godly in Christ Jesus shall suffer persecucio^. But
wicked men and miscariers shall wax worse and worse, errynge, and bringynge
into error. 2. Tim. 1. c
But abide you in those things yt thou have learned, and are committed unto
the, knowing of whom thou have learned them, and that thou have known the
holy scriptures fro thy youth, the which are able to instruct the unto
salvation, through the faith that is in Christ Jesus. 2. Petri. 1. d
For all scripture being inspired from heaven is profitable to teach, to
rebuke, to correcke, to enfourme in righteousness, that the man of God be
perfect, taught unto every good work.

The.iiii. Chapter.
I Testifye before God and 2. Petri. 1. c
For I am now offered, and ye time of mine vnlowsynge is at hand. I have foghten
a good fight, Ioh. 17. a
I have fulfilled my course, I have kept the 1. Cor. 9. d 1. Petri. 5. a
a crown of righteousness for me, the which the LORD the ryghteous judge
shall give me in that day: and not only unto me, but also the^ that love his
coming. Make hayst to come soon unto me. For Coll. 4. b Philip. 1. c
Demas has left me, loving this world, and is gone to Thessalonica,
Cresce^s in Galatia, Titus in Dalmatia, Lucas only is with me. Take Coll. 1. ^
Mark and bring him with the, for he is profitable unto me in ye service.
Tychicus have I sent to Ephesus. The cloak yt I have left at Troas with
Carpus, coming bring it with the, and the books, but specially ye
parcheme^tes. 1. Tim. ^. ^
Alexander ye coppersmyth has showed to me much evil, ye LORD shall restore
him according to his works whom do thou also eschew: for he did greatly
wythstande our words Act. 18. a Romans 16. a.
Priscilla and Aquila, and ye house of Onesiphorus. Romans 16. c
Erastus did remain at Corinthus. But Act. 21. d
Trophimus have I left sick at Miletus. Make haist to come before winter.
Eubulus, and Pudens, and Linus, and Claudia, and all the brethren do salute
the. The LORD Jesus Christ be with thy sprete. Grace be with you. AMEN.

The end of the second Epistle of Paul the Apostle to Timothe.
The Epistle of the Apostle Paul to Titus.
The first Chapter.
^. Tim. 1. b

Philip. 1. a
God the father, and Christ Jesus our Saueoure. For this 1. Tim. 3. a
For a bishop must be blameless, as mat. 24. d 1. Cor. 4. a

not desirous of fylthy lucre: but harberous, gentle, wise, sobre, ryghteous,
holy, te^perate, 2. Es^. 4. c

For there are many 2. Tim. 3. a
which subuerte whole houses, teaching things that they ought not, because
of fylthy lucre. One of their own prophets said: The Cretians are always
liars, evil beasts, Epimenides
slow bellyes. That witness is true. Wherefore rebuke the^ sharply, that they
may be sound in ye faith, not geuynge head to Iewysh fables, and
commandments of men turnynge from the faith. Math. 12. a and.23. c
All things are clean unto the clean: but To. 14. c
unto the unclean and unbelieving is nothing clean, but their mind and
conscience are defiled. They confess them to know God, but with the deeds
they deny him: seeing they are abominable, and unbelieving, and unmeet unto
every good work.

The.ii. Chapter.
1. Tim. 2. b
The elder women likewise yt they use holy apparel, 1. Tim. 5. b

faythfulnesse in all things, that they garnysh the doctrine of God our

all men, teaching us, that we denyenge ungodliness and 1. Ioh. 2. c

waytyng for the blessed Math. 25. c

The.iii. Chapter.
ADmonish Romans 13. a 1. Pet. 2. c
them to be obediente Romans 1^. b. c
to speak evil of noman, to be no stryuers, but soft, showing all
gentlynesse toward all men. For we ourselves also were sometime foolyshe,
unbelieving, going astraye, serving diverse desires and pleasures, living in
malice and envy, hateful, hatynge each other. 2. Tim. 1. b
But wha^ the kyndnesse and gentlynesse of our Saueoure God had appeared, not
of the works of righteousness that we have done, but according to his mercy
has Romans 8. c
he saved us, through Ioh. 3. ^ Ephesians. 6. a
the fountain of the new birth and renewynge of ye holy ghost, who^ he has

being made ryghteous Act. 15. b Ephesians. 2. a

words: for they are unprofitable and vain. Math. 18. b ^. Tess. 3. a Roma.
16. b
Eschew the man that is given to sects after the first and second admonicion,

condemned by his own judgment. When I shall have sent Artemas unto ye or
Tychicus, make haist to come unto me to Nicopolis: for there have I purposed to
winter. Send Zenas the lawer and Act. 1^. c 1. Cor. 1. b ^. a. 16. b
Apollo diligently before, that nothing be wantynge unto them. And let ours
learn to excel in good works unto necessary uses, that they be not
frutelesse. All they that are with me do salute the. Salute them that love us
in faith. The Grace of God be with you all. Amen.

The end of the Epistle of Paul the Apostle to Titus.
The Epistle of Paul the Apostle to Philemon.
The first Chapter.
Paul the presoner of Col. 4. b
Archippus our fellowsouldyour, and unto the congregation that is in thy house
1. Cor. 1. a 2. Cor. 1. a Gal. 1. ^
Grace be unto you and peace from God our father, and the LORD Jesus Christ. I
thank my God, making always a remembrance of ye in all my prayers, hearing
of thy love and the faith that thou have in the LORD Jesus, and unto al
saints, that the fellowship of thy faith be evident in the knowledge of every
good work in you in Christ Jesus. For I had great joy and consolacio^ in thy
love, because that the entrayles of the saints (brother) did rest Coll. 4. ^
Onesimus my son, whom I have begotten in bands: which sometime was
unprofitable unto the, but now profitable both unto me and unto ye, whom I have
sent again unto the. But receive thou him (that is mine entrayles,) whom I would
have kept with me, that he might have ministered unto me in the bands of the
Gospel in stead of the: but I would do nothing without thy counsel, that the
good that thou do were not as of co^pulsion, but with a good Coll. 1. ^
and.4. b
Epaphras my fellowpresoner saluteth the in Christ Jesus, [and] Mark,
Aristarchus, Demas and Luke, my helpers The grace of our LORD Jesus Christ be
with your sprete. Amen.

The end of the Epistle of the Apostle Paul unto Philemon.
The Epistle of Paul the Apostle to the Hebrews.
The first Chapter.
GOd speaking in times Math. ^8. c
whom he has made heir of al things, by whom also he has made the world.
The which seeing Sap. 7. d 2. Cor. 4. a Coll. 1. d
he is the bryghtnesse of the glory, and the figure of his substance, bearing
up al things by the word of his power, Ephesians. 1. ^
making a clensynge of sins, he sytteth at the ryghtha^de of the majesty in
ye heyght: being become so much better tha^ angels, as Math. 1. c Luce. 2. a
Philip. 2. ^
he has optayned by heretage a more excellent name tha^ they. For unto whom
of Psalm. 2. a Act. 13. d
Thou art my son, this day have I begotten the? And again: 2. Reg. 7. c
I shall be a father unto him, and he shall be a son unto me. And when he
brings the first begotten son again into the compass of ye world, he
says: Psalm. 96. a
And let all the angels of God worship him. And unto ye angels truly says
he: Psalm. 103. a
Which makes his angels spretes, and his ministers a flame of fire. But unto
the son. Psalm. 44. b
Thy seat God is for ever and ever, the rod of thy kingdom is a rod of
ryghteousnes. Thou have loved righteousness, and have hated wyckednes,
therefore has God, even thy God anointed the with oil of gladness above thy
companions. And: Psalm. 10^. d
Thou LORD dyddest create the earth at the beginning, and the heavens are the
works of thy hands. Psalm. 101. d Esai. 51. b 2. Petri. 3. b
They shall perysh, but thou shall endure, and they all shall wax old as a
garmente. And as a cloth shalt thou change them, and they shall be changed:
but thou art even the same, and thy years shall not fail. But unto whom of
the angels said he at any time: Psalm. 109. a
Sit thou at my ryghthande, until I lay thine enemies a foot stool of thy
fete? Are they not all ministrynge spretes, sent to the ministracion, because
of the^ that do receive the heretage of salvation?

The.ii. Chapter.
Genesis 18. c and.19. c
that was spoken by angels, became sure, and every transgression and
disobedience did receive a due recompense of reward: how shall we escape if
we shall despise so great a salvation? the which Marc. 1. b
after that it began first to be preached by the LORD, by the^ that herd it,
Marci. 16. c
it was confyrmed upon us, God bearing witness Act. 15. b
with tokens, and wonders, and diverse miracles, and gifts of ye holy ghost, For
one testifyeth in a place, saying: Psalm. 8. d
What is man, that thou art myndeful of him? or the son of of man, because
you do visit him? Thou haste made him a little less than the angels, thou
have crowned him with honor and glory, and have set him above the works of
thy hands. All things have thou put in subieccion under his fete. 1. Cor. 15.
c
For in that he has put all things under him, he has left nothing yt is
not put under him. Nevertheless now do not we yet se all things put under
him. But him which is made a little less tha^ the angels [namely] Jesus, we se
Pilip. 2. a
to be crowned with glory and honor, by the reason of the sufferynge of
death, that by the grace of God he 1. Cor. 15. f
should taiste of death for all men. For it became him, for whose sake are all
things, and by whom are all things, which had brought many children unto
glory, the author of their salvation, to be made perfect through sufferynge.
For he that sanctifyeth, and they that are sanctified, are all of one. For the
which Psalm. 21. c
I shall show thy name unto my brethren, in the mids of the congregation will
I praise the. And again: Psalm. 17. a Esai. 12. a
I shall be trustyng in him. And again: Esaias. 8. d
Behold, here am I, and the children which God has given me. Because
therefore that children have taken part with flesh and blood, Pilipi 2. ^
he likewise has also taken part with the^, Osee. 13. c 1. Cor. 15. ^ 2. Tim.
1. b
that by death he might destroy him, which had the rule of death: that is,
the deuell, and that he might deliver them that were in bondage all their life
time, by reason of ye fear of death. For he takes no where the angels upon
him, but the sede of Abraham takes he upon him. Wherefore he ought ^^llip. ^. a
to be like unto his brethren in all things, that he might become a mercyful
and faithful bishop by God, that he might be favorable unto the peoples
sins. Heb. 5. a
For in that thing wherein he suffered and was proved, he is able to help them
also that are tempted.

The.iii. Chapter.
1. Cor. 4. a
faithful unto him that has ordyned him, even Nu. 12. a
as Moses also in all his house. For this man was counted worthy of greater
glory before Moses, as he has more praise that buyldeth a house, tha^ the
house it self. For every house is builded of some body, Genesis 1. a
but he that created all things, it is God. And Moses truly was faithful in all
his house like a servant, Deuteronomy. 18. c
for a witness of those things that were to be spoken: But Christ like as a
child in his own house, ^. Cor. 3. b and.6. c
the which house are we if we shall keep steadfast the confidence and
reioycynge of Romans 5. a
hope unto the end. Wherefore as says the holy ghost: Psalm. 94. b
To day if ye shall hear his voice, harden not ye your hearts, Exodus 17. a
as in the provoking to anger according to the day of temptacio^ in the
wilderness, where your fathers did te^pte me, they proved me and Deuteronomy. 11. ^
saw my works forty year. Wherefore I was wroth with this generacio^, and
said: These do ever err with their hearts. But they did not know my ways,
unto who^ I did swear in mine anger, yt they shall not enter into my rest.
Take Hebre. 13. b
to day, that none of you be hardened with the deceatfulnesse of sin. For we
are become partakers of Christ, Mat. 10. c and.24. a
if we at the leest keep sure the beginning of his substance unto the end,
until it is said. Psalm. 94. b
To day if ye shall hear his voice, harden not your hearts, as in that
provoking to anger. For some as they herd, did provoke to anger, but not all
they that went out of Egipte by Moses. But with whom was he angry the fortye
years? Was it not with them that did sin, whose bodies were overthrown in
the deserte? Number. 14. ^
But unto whom did he swear not to enter into his rest* save unto them that
were vnbelyuynge? And we se that they could not enter into his rest because
of unbelief.

The.iiii. Chapter.
LEt us therefore fear lest to be wantyng: For it is showed unto us also, as
unto them. Esaias. 7. b Roma. 2. b
But the word of the preaching did not avail them, not being myxte with the

my rest. And truly [yt spoke he] wha^ ye works from the creacion of ye world
were fynyshed. For he said in a certain place of the seventh day on this
wise: Genesis 2. a
And God rested the seventh day from all his works. And in this place again:

They Psalm. 94. b

as Esa. 49. a Ephe. 6. b

The.v. Chapter.
FOr every high pressed taken Leuit. 9. b.
he do offer up gifts and sacrifices for sins, which may be able to have
compassion of the^ yt are ignorant and are out of the way, because yt he also
is clothed with infirmite: and therefore ought he as for ye people, so to offer for
him self also for ye sins. Another does any man take the honor upon him,
but he that is called of God, Exodus ^^. a Number. 1^. a
like as Aaron also. And even so did not Christ glorifye himself, that he
should become a high priest, but he that spoke unto him: Psalm. 2. a
Thou art my son, this day have I begotten the. Like as he says also in
another place: Psalm. 109. a
Thou art a priest forever after the order of Melchisedek, Luc. 23. c Ioh. 17.
a
which offering up prayers and supplicacio^s in ye days of his flesh unto
him, which was able to save him from death, with great cry and tears, he was
herd according Pilip. 2. a
And truly when he was Gods son, he learned obedience by those things yt he
suffered. And being made perfect he became unto al them yt obey him, ye cause
of everlasting salvation, called of god the high pressed after ye order of
Melchisedek: Whereof we have a great matter and interpretable to speak, for ye
are become weak to hear. 1. Cor. 3. a
For where ye ought to be masters by reason of ye time, ye need again to be
taught which be ye principles of ye beginning of ye words of god, and are
become such as have need of milk, and not strong meat. For every one yt is
partaker of ye milk, is not partner of ye word of righteousness: for he is a
babe. But strong meat belongs unto the^ yt be perfect, those yt by reason
of ye use have exercised wits to the judgment of good and evil.

The.vi. Chapter.
Act. 18. c Jacob. 4. b
if God shall permytte it. Heb. 10. c
For it is impossible them that have been lyghtened, have also taysted the
heavenly gift, and are become partakers of the holy gooste, have nevertheless
^. Petri. 2. d
taysted of the good word of God, and the powers of the world to come, and
are fallen away, to be renewed again unto repentance, crucifyenge unto
themselves the son of God again and making a mock of him. For Math. 25. d
For God is not unjust yt he do forget your work and love, the which ye have
showed in his name, which have ministered unto ye saints, and do ministre. But
we desire every one of you to show the same carfulness, to the fulfyllynge
of ye hope until the end, yt ye become not slothful, but their followers
which shall enherete the promyses by faith and patience. For God promising
unto Abraham, because he had noman greater by whom he might swear, Genesis 2^. c
he did swear by himself, saying: Without that blessing I shall bless the,
and multyenge I shall multiplye the. And so having patience a long season, he
gat the promise. For men do Exodus 22. b
and an oath is the end to confyrme all their controversy. In the which thing
God willing more plentyfullyer to show unto ye heirs of the promyses, ye
stablenesse of his counsel, he put an oath between, that by two immovable
things, by the which it is impossible for god to lie, we may have a most
sure comfort we yt fly to lay hold on the hope set before us the which we
have as a sure and steadfast anchor of our soul and entering in until the
inmoost of the veil, where the forerunner Jesus is gone in for us, being made
high pressed for ever after the order of Melchisedek.

The.vii. Chapter.
Genesis 14. a
the king of Salem, the pressed of the most high God, which met Abraham being
returned from the slaughter of the kings, and blessed him* unto whom did
Abraham also deal tithes of all things: first truly is he that is called
king of righteousness, but afterward king of Salem, which is to say king
of peace without father, without mother, with out kynne, having another
beginning of days, nor end of life, but lykened unto the son of God,
remains a pressed for ever. And behold how great this is, unto whom Abraham the
patriarch also gave tithes of ye chefest. Number. 18. d ^. Par. 31. b
And verily they of the children of Leui that receive ye presthode, have a
commandment to take tithes according to the law, that is, of their
brethren, although they also be come out of the loins that dye receive
tithes, but there does he witness that he lives: and (that it may be so
said) Leui also which receaueth tithes was tythed by Abraham: for he was yet
in his fathers loins when Melchisedek met him. Romans ^. b Gal. 2. c
If the perfeccion therefore was by the presthode of Leui, (for the people
received the law under the same:) what was it need yet to rise another priest
after the order of Melchisedek and not to be called after the order of Aaron?
Mala. 2. b
For the presthode being translated, it is necessary that there be also a
translacion of the law. For he of whom these things are spoken, is of an
other trybe, of the which no man served at the altar. For it is euidente Mat.
1. a. b
that our LORD is spro^ge of the trybe of Judah, in the which tribe Moses has
spoken nothing of the prestes. And it is yet more manifest, if according to
the lykenes of Melchisedek do rise onother pressed which is not made after the
law of the carnal commandment, but after the power of the vnlowseable
life. For he witnesses: that Psalm. 109. a
Thou art a priest forever, after the order of Melchisedek. Truly the
disanullynge of the first commandment is happened because of his weakness
and unprofitableness: Romans 3. b and.8. a Gal. 3. b c. d. 4. a
for the law brought nothing to perfectness, but [it was] an introduccion of
a better hope, by ye which we approach unto God. And for so much as it is not
without an oath. (For other truly are made prestes without an oath, but
the same with an oath, by him which said unto him: Psalm. 109. a
The LORD has sworn, and it shall not repent him: Thou art a pressed for
ever,) so much is Jesus become 1. Tim. 2. a 1. Ioh. 2. a
to make intercession for us. For such one seemed to be an high pressed unto us,
holy, innocent, undefiled, sundered from sinners, and being made higher tha^
the heavens, which has no need daily ( Leui. 9. b
as the high prests) to offer up sacrifices, first for his sins, and than for
the peoples: for yt has he done offering himself once. Heb. 5. b
For ye law makes men prestes having weakness: but ye word of ye oath,
which is after ye law, the son being perfect for ever.

The.viii. Chapter.
Hebre. 3. a 6. c. 9. b
We have such an high pressed, which is set on Ephesians. 1. c. Psalm. 109. a 1.
Petri. 3. c
ye rightha^de of ye seat of ye greatness in ye heavens, a minister of ye
saints and of the true tabernacle, yt which God has pyghte ^ not man. For
every high pressed is ordyned to offer up gifts and sacrifices, wherefore it is
necessary for the same also to have yt he may offer up. If he were therefore upon
earth, another were he a pressed, seeing there be ye offer up gifts according to
ye law, Heb. 10. a
the which do serve unto ye example and shadow of heavenly things, as it was
answered unto Moses wha^ he fynyshed the tabernacle: Exodus 25. d Act. 7. f
Se (says he) that thou do all things according to the ensample that was
showed ye upon the mount. But now has he Iere. 31. ^
Behold, the days shall come says the LORD, and I shall fynysh a new
testamente upon the house of Israel and upon the house of Judah, not according
to the testament that I made unto their fathers, in ye day when I took their
hand, yt I might lead them out of the land of Egypt: Act. 7. ^
for they did not abide in my testamente, and I have not regarded the^ Esai. 51.
b Iere. 31. f
For this is ye testament that I shall ordyne unto ye house of Israel after
those days says ye LORD: I will give my laws in their mind, and in their
heart will I write them: zacha. 8. b Apoc. 21. b
and I shall be a God unto them, and they shall be a people unto me. And every one
shall not teach his neighbor, and every one his brother, saying: Know the
LORD, for they shall know me from ye leest unto ye most of the^: For I shall be
mercyful unto their wyckednesses, and I shall not now remember their sins.
But saying ye new he wears out yt was before. And it yt is worn out and
waxes old, is near to ye peryshing.

The.ix. Chapter.
Exodus 25. a
For first was the tabernacle made, in the which were the candelstickes, and the
table, and Leuit. 24. b
yt show breades, the which is called holy. But behind the veil was ye
second tabernacle, the which is called the most holy, having the golden
censoure, and Exodus 25. b
the Arc of the conuenaunte ouerlayde on every side with gold, wherein was
Exodus 16. f
the golden pot having the Manna, and the rod of Aaron, Number. 17. a
which floryshed and the Exodus 40. c
tables of the testamente. And above the same were the cherubins of glory,
ouershadowyng ye mercy seat, whereof it is not now to speak particularly. Number.
28. a
And wha^ ye things were thus dressed, in the first tabernacle truly entered
always ye prestes, fulfyllynge the offices of sacrifices: Exodus 30. b Leuit.
16. g Luce. 1. a
but in the second ye high pressed only once in the year, not without blood,
the which he should offer for Johan. 10. a and.14. a
the way of the holynesses was not yet uttered the first tabernacle having yet
his being. The which is a similitude of the present time, according to the
which gifts and sacrifices are offered, the which can not make perfect as
concerning ye conscience the seruer only in meats, and drynkes, and in sundry
washynges, and ryghteousnesses of the flesh, set in until the time of
correccion. Hebre. 5. c 6. a. 8. a
But Christ coming by, a high pressed of good things to come, he is gone once
into the holy places by a more larger and more perfecter Esaie. 33. c 2. Cori.
5. a
tabernacle, not made with hands, yt is, not of this making, another by ye
blood of goats or calves, 1. Ioha^. 1. b. 1. Petri. 1. c Apoc. 1. a
but by his own blood, having found eternal redemcion. Leui. 9. b and.16. b
For if ye blood of goats or of oxen Nu. 19. b
and the ashes of a cow sprenkled sanctifyeth the unclean unto the clensynge
of the Ephe. 1. a Coloss. 1. b 2. Corin. 5. c
which through the holy ghost has offered himself unspotted unto God, cleansed
our conscience from dead works, Romans 6. a 1. Petr. 4. a
to serve the living God? And therefore is he Gala. 3. c 1. Tim. 2. a
a mediatoure of the new testament, that by the mean of death, they that are
called may receive the promise of eternal heretage, into rede^pcion of those
transgressions, which were under the first testament, For where there is a
testament, it is necessary that ye death of the testament maker do pass. Gal.
3. ^
For the testament is confyrmed by the dead, or else it is yet of no value so
long as he yt makes the testament lives. Wherefore another was ye first
testament ordyned without blood. For wha^ every commandment of ye law was
red of Moses unto all the people, taking ye blood of calves and goats with
water and purple woll and ysope, he spre^kled both ye book and all ye people,
saying: Exodus 24. b
This is ye blood of the testament, ye which God has commanded unto you. The
tabernacle also and all ye vessels of ye service sprenkled he with blood
likewise. And neareha^d al things are cle^sed with blood after the law, and
without sheddynge of blood is there no remyssion. It is therefore necessary
truly ye similitudes of heavenly things to be cle^sed with these, but ye
heavenly things themselves with better sacrifices than these. For Jesus entered
not in holy places Act. 7. f and.17. d
made with hands, the ensamples of the true, but in the very heaven, that 1.
Ioha^. 2. a
he may now appear unto the sight of God for us: Another that he offer
himself often, like Leuit. 16. g
as the high pressed enters every year into the holy places with strange blood:
(orels behooved it him often to suffr^ from the beginning of the world.) But
now in ye fynishynge of the times has he appeared once by his own offering
unto the putting away of sin. And as it is ordined for men once to dye, but
after that shall be the judgment: Romans 5. a 1. Petri. 3. c
eue^ so is Christ once offered, to take away the sins of many. The second
time shall he appear without sin unto al them yt wayt for him unto salvation.

The.x. Chapter.
Colloss. 2. c
having a shadow of the good things to come, not the very fashion of the
things, ca^ never make the co^mers unto it perfect with the very same
sacrifices, which they offer without ceassynge every year: orels had they
ceased to be offered, because that the worshippers once cleansed should have no
more conscience of sin: but in the^ is every year made a remembrance of
sins. Leuit. 16. c
For it is impossible sins to be taken away with the blood of oxen and goats.
Therefore, entryng into the world he says: Esaye. 50. b Psalm. 39. b
Sacrifice and offering would thou not have, but thou have prepared a body
unto me. Burntofferynges and sin offerynges pleased the not. Than said I: Lo
I come. In the beginning of the book is there written of me, that I should do
thy will, O God. Saying above, that: Sacrifices and offerynges, and
burntofferinges, and sin offerynges thou would not, another are they things
pleasynge unto the, yt are offered after ye law, than said I: Lo, I come, that
I may do thy will o God: he takes away the first yt he may ordyne the
ensuynge: In the which will we are hallowed, by the offering once of Psalm.
109. a
until his enemies be set a stool for his fete. For with one offering has he
made perfect forever them that are sanctified. And ye holy ghost bears
record with us. For after yt he had said: Iere. 31. ^
And this is the testament that I shall make with them after those days,
says the LORD: I will give my laws in their hearts, and in their minds will
I write them, and I will no more remember their sins and wyckednesses. But
seeing the remission of these is, tha^ is there now no more offering for sin.
Ioha^. 10. a and.14. a Romans 5. a Heb. 9. b
boldness in the entrance of holy things in the blood of Christ, ye which
new way and living he has prepared unto us through the veil, that is, his
flesh, and the high pressed over the house of God, let us come near with a true
heart in the fullness of faith, Heb. 9. c 1. Petri. 1. a
having our hearts sprenkled from an evil conscience, and having the body
washen with clean water, let us hold fast the knowlegynge of our faith not
wauerynge: for he is faithful that has promised. And let us consydre each
other in the provoking of charity and good works, not leaving our
handreachynge, as some have a costume to do: but comfortyng, and that so much
more as Romans 13. b
ye shall se the day approchynge the more. Nu. 15. c Hebr. 6. a
For unto us synnynge wyllingly after the knowledge of the truth is received,
there is left now no sacrifice for sins: but a fearful waiting for the
judgment, and a heat of fire, which shall consume the adversaries. Deuteronomy. 17.
b and.19. c
If any makes the law of Moses void, he dies wtoute mercy under two or three
witnesses: how much more worse Deuteronomy. 32. ^ Romans 12. c
[Yelde] unto me the vengeance, and I shall recompense. And again: Deu. 32. e
God shall judge his people. It is a dredefull thing to fall into the hands
of the living God. But call to mind ye days past, in the which being
lyghtened, ye suffered a great strife of sufferynges: of the one part truly ye
are become a gasynge stock with the shames and troubles, but of the other
part ye are become companions of them that were so co^uersau^t. Math. 25. c 2.
Tim. 1. c
For ye have both suffered with the^ that were presoners, and took with joy the
spoylynge of your goods, knowing you to have a better and during substance.
Lose not therefore your confidence, which has a great reward. Hebre. 12. a
For patience is needful unto you, that doing the will of God, ye may
receive the promise. Abac. 2. a
For it is yet a short and a little while, he that is coming shall come and
shall not tarry? Romans 1. b Galat. 3. b
But my ryghteous shall live by faith: If so be he shall wythdrawe himself, he
shall not please unto my soul. But we are not children of wythdrawynge unto
perdicio^, but of faith, unto the purchasing of the soul.

The.xi. Chapter.
ANd faith is a substance Romans 1. d and.8. c Coloss. 1. b
do not appear. For by ye same have ye elders optayned a report. By faith do
we understand Gene. 1. a*
the world to have been ordyned, by ye word of God, yt of invisible things
they might become visible. Gene. 4. a
By faith did Abell offer a more plentyfull sacrifice unto God than Cain, by
the which he optayned a report to be ryghteous, his gifts bearing witness
unto God, and being dead, he speaks yet by the same. Genes. 5. c Sapi. 4. b
Eccl. 44. b and.49. c
By faith was Enoch translated, lest he should se death, and he was not found,

had pleased God. Genesis 6. d Eccli. 41. b
By faith Noe after that he had received the answer, fearyng those things that

The.xii. Chapter.
ANd therefore we having Ephe. 4 c Col^. 3. a 1. Petri. ^.
layenge away all the weight and sin that stands by us, let us run by
patience unto the strife that is set before us, lokynge upon the author and
fynysher of faith Jesus, Philip. 2. a
which the joy being set before him suffered the cross, shame despised,
Hebre. 1. a and.10. b
and sytteth at the ryghthande of the seat of God. Remember him than that
suffered such speaking against himself of sinners, yt ye be not weery,
waxynge faynte in your minds. For ye have not yet resysted until blood,
stryuyng against sin, and have forgotten ye co^solacion which speaks unto
you as unto children, saying: Prouer. 3. b
My son, despise not the nourtoure of ye LORD, another do faint when you art
rebuked of him. Apoc. ^. b
For whom ye LORD loves, does he chaste^, and scourges every son whom he
receaueth. Remain days enfourmed us according to their will: but this unto
it yt is profitable to receive his holiness. And every chastenyng for the
present time seems not to be of joy, but of sorrow, but afterward shall it
give them yt are exercysed by the same, a most quiet fruit of righteousness
For yt which cause Esa. 35. a
lift up ye slacked hands, and ye lowsed knees, and make straight paths unto
your fete, yt noma^ halting do go astraye, but rather Romans 12. c
Follow upon peace with al men, and holiness, without ye which noma^ shall se God,
taking head yt noma^ be destitute of ye grace of God, lest any root of
bytternesse spryngynge upward do let, and by the same many be stained. That
there be no whoremonger or unclean person as Esau, Genesis 25. d
that sold his byrthryghte for one meat. For be sure yt afterward also
desyryng to enheret, he was refused: Gene. ^7. f
for he f^de no place of repe^tau^ce, though he had sought it with tears. For ye
are not come to a mountain yt can be handled, and Exodus 20. c
a fire yt ca^ be approached, and myste, and darkness, and tempest, and the
sou^de of ye tro^pe, and the voice of words: (the which they yt did hear, did
excuse themselves, yt the word should not happen unto the^. For they could not
bear yt was spoken. And Exodus 19. b
if a beast shall touch the mountain, it shall be stoned. And so terrible was it
yt was seen, [that] Moses Apoc. 2^. b
ye celestial Jerusalem, and the multitude of many thousand of angels, and ye
co^gregacio^ of the fyrstborne, which are written in the heavens, and God the

sprenklynge of blood, speaking better tha^ Gene. 4. b
Abels. Se that ye refuse not him yt speaks. For if they escaped not
refusing him yt spoke upon earth: much more we, yt refuse him ye speaks unto
us from the heavens, whose voice did shake the earth at ye time, but now
promyseth, saying: Agg^^. 2. b
Yet once again, and I shall shake, not only the earth, but also heaven. But
that he says yet once, he declares the chaungynge of the mouable, as done,
that those things that are immovable may remain. Receauynge therefore the
immovable kingdom, we have grace, 1. Petri. 2. a
by ye which we may serve pleasing God with fear and reverence: Deuteronomy. 4. d
for our God is a co^sumynge fire.

The.xiii. Chapter.
LEt ye love of brotherheade Gene. 18. a and.19. a Romans 12. b 1. Petr. 4. b
and forget not hospitalite: for by the same some were acceptable, receauynge
angels at lodging. Math. 25. c Heb. 10. d
Remember them that are bound, as bound with them: and of the^ that are in
pain, as ye yourselues abydyng also in ye body. Let wedlock be honorable in all things, and ye bed undefiled For God shall judge ye whoremo^gers and
aduouterers. Let your manners be without covetousness, Eccli. 29. d
being content with the things yt ye have already: for he said: Deuteronomy. 31. b
Ios^e. 1. a
I will not leave nor forsake y^, so yt we may boldly say: Psalm. 55. a and.117 a
The Lord is my helper, I shall not be afraid what man do unto me. Remember
them that have ye ouersyght of you, which have spoken the word of God unto
you, beholdynge the end of whose co^uersacion, Hebre. 3. b
to day, he abides forever. Be not miscarried with sundry and strange
doctrines. Romans 14. c Coloss. 2. c Titum. 3. c
For it is best to stay the heart with grace, Ioh. 6. f
not with meats, which did not avail the^ that did walk in the^. We have an
altar, whereof they have no power to eat yt serve the tabernacle. Exodus 29. b
Leuit. 4. c Number. 19. a
For those beasts, yt the blood is brought into ye holy places by ye high
pressed for sin, the bodies of the^ are burnt without the tents. For the which
cause Jesus also, yt he might hallowe ye people by his blood, Ioha^. 19. b
did suffer without the gate. Let us therefore go forth unto him without the
tents, bearyng his rebuke. Pilip. 3. c
For we have not here an abiding city, but we seek one Psalm. 91. a
Let us therefore always offer the sacrifice of praise unto God through him, yt
is ye fruit of [our] lyppes, knowlegynge unto his name. And forget not the
doing well 1. Cori. 16. a
and the handreachynge: Pilip. 4. c
for with such sacrifyces is God made favorable. Obey your overseers, and
be obediente unto them: for they watch for you, as though they shall give an
account for you, that they may do it with joy, and not syghynge: for ye does
not become you. Act. 4. c and.1^. a Ephesians. 6. c
Pray for us: for we trust that we have a good conscience, willing in all
things to be conuersau^t well. But I beseke you to do ye same yet more, yt I
may be restored unto you ye more spedely. The God of peace, which has Ezec.
34. b Ioh. 10. a 1. Petri. 5. a
the great shepeherd of the sheep, through the blood of the eternal
testamente, Deuteronomy. 8. d 2. Cori. 5. a Pilip. 2. b
make you mete in all goodness, that ye may do his will, workynge among you
that may please in his sight through Jesus Christ, unto whom be glory for ever
and ever. Amen I beseke you brethren that ye suffer ye word of solace, for I
have written unto you with very few [wordes.] Know our brother Timothe to be
lette^ go, with whom (if he shall come spedely) I will se you. Great al your
over seers, and all the saints. The brethren of Italy salute you. Grace be
with you all. Amen.

The end of the Epistle of Paul the Apostle to the Hebrews.
The catholyke Epistle of the Apostle James.
The first Chapter.
James the servant Actu. 8. ^
are scattred. Count it full joy my brethren when ye do fall into sundry
temptacions, being sure, that Romans 5. a
the prouyng of your faith works patience: 1. Petri. 1. b zach. 13. b
but let patience have a perfect workynge, that ye may be perfect and
sound, faydyng in nothing. Prouer. 2. a Ioh. 16. c
But if any of you needs wisdom, let him require it of God, which gives
plentyfully unto every man, and vpbraydeth not, and it shall be given him Marc.
11. c
But let him require it i^ faith not doutynge. For he that douteth is like unto
ye wawe of ye see, which is steared of the wind and is tossed about: let not
therefore that man suppose that he shall receive ought of ye Eccli. 14. d Esa.
40. a 1. Petri. 1. d
Son arose with heat, and dried ye grass, and his flower fell down, and
the bewty of his syghte peryshed. Even so shall the rich also fayde in his
ways. Job. 5. b
Happy is the man that suffers tentacion: for when he shall be proved, he shall
receive a crown of life, the which God has promised to them that love him.
Let noman when he is tempted say that he is tempted of God. For God is no
te^ter of the evil, and he tempts noman. But every one is tempted, being
drawn and entysed of his own concupiscence: afterward when Romans 6. d
concupiscence has conceived, she enge^dreth sin: but sin when it is
fynyshed, it enge^dreth death. Err not therefore my most beloved brethren
Prouer. 2. a Ioh. 3. d
Every best gift, and every perfect gift is from above, coming down from
the father of lyghtes, by whom there is no change, nor course of
ouershadowynge. Ioha^. 1. a and.3. d 1. Cori. 4. d
For wyllyngly has he engendered us with ye word of truth, that we be some
beginning of his creature. For ye know it my most beloved brethren. But
Prou. 17. d Eccli. 5. b
let every man be swyft to hear but slow to speak, and slow to wrath For the
wrath of man works not the ryghteousnes of God. Romans 13. b Coloss. 3. a
Castyng Romans 2. b.
And be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceauynge yourselues. Luc.
6. c
For if any man be an hearer of ye word, and not a doer, the same shall be
lykened unto a man beholdynge the vysage of his birth in a glass: for he did
behold himself and went, and forthwith did he forget of what fashion he was.
Math. 5. b
But he yt shall look in the law of perfect lyberte, and shall remain in
the same, not being become a forgetful hearer, but an accomplysher of the
work, the same shall be happy in his deed. But if any man thinks him to be
devout, not refraynyng his 1. Petri. 3. d Jacob. 3. a
tunge, but myscaryenge his heart, this man's devotion is vain. Pure and
unspotted devotion by God and the father is this: To vysyte the fatherless and
motherlesse and the wedowes in their trouble, and to keep himself undefiled
from this 1. Ioha^. 2. c
world.

The.ii. Chapter.
Leuit. 19. d
regard of persons. For if there enter into your congregation a man having a
golden ring, in a goodly apparel, and there shall also enter in a poor man in
a vile raiment, and ye do look upon him that is clothed with a gaye raymente,
and shall say unto him: Sit thou well here. And to the poor ye shall say:
Stand thou there, or sit down under the foot stool of my fete: do not ye
judge by yourselues, and are become Math. 5. a
Harken my most beloved brethren: Has not God chosen the poor in this world
the rych in faith and heirs of the kingdom, the which god has promised them
that love him? But ye have dishonored the poor. Do not the rich oppress you
by might, and draw you to the judgment? Do not they blaspheme the good name
that is called upon you? If ye at the leest fulfill ye royal law according to
the scriptures: Leuit. 19. c
Thou shall love thy neighbor as thyself, ye do well: but if ye regard the
person, ye do sin, being rebuked of the law, as transgressors. Ezech. 18.
b
But who so ever keeps the whole law, and offends in one, he is become
gylty of all. For he that has said: Exodus 20. c
Thou shall not commytte aduoutry, has said also: Thou shalt not kyl. But if
you shalt not commyt aduoutry, but shall slaye, thou art become a
transgressoure of the law. Speak ye so, and do so, as beginning to be judged
by the law of lyberte. Math. 18. ^
For judgment without mercy shall be unto him yt shows no mercy. And mercy
exalts judgment. Math. 7. ^
What does it avail my brethren if any man do say him to have faith, but has
no works? Can faith save him? 1. Ioh. 3. c
But if a brother and sister be naked, and do need daily food, and any of you
do say unto them: Go in peace, be warmed and be satisfied, but ye shall not
give them ye things that are necessary to the body, what shall it avail? Even
so faith also, if she has no works, is dead in herself. But some body will
say: Mat. 8. d Marc. 1. c
the deuels do also believe and tremble. But will thou know o thou vain man
that faith without works is dead? Was not Abraham our father justified by
works, offering Isaac his son upon the altar? Seyst thou not that faith
wrought with his works, and by works was faith made perfect? And the
scripture was fulfilled, saying: Genesis 15. c Romans 4. b Gal. 3. a
Abraham believed God, and it was counted him unto righteousness, and he was
called the friend of God. Se ye not that man is justified by works and not by
faith only? Like wise also Ios. 2. a and.6. c
Raab the harlot, was she not justified, receauyng the messau^gers, and sending
the^ another way? For as ye body without ye sprete is dead, eue^ so faith also
without works is dead.

The.iii. Chapter.
Math. 23. a
masters, knowing that ye receive the more judgment. For we al offend in
many things. Eccli. 14. a 19. c. and.25. b
He that offe^deth not in word, ye same is a perfect man, is able also to
lead about ye whole body with a bridle. And if we do put brydles in horses
mouths, we lead all their bodies about to consent unto us. And behold the
ships while they be great, and be led with great wyndes, with a little helm
are they turned about where ye violence of the gouernoure will. Eue^ so also
the tunge, it is a little member truly, and it exalts great things. Genesis 1.
d
are created after the image and similitude of God. Out of ye very same mouth
comes forth blessing and cursynge. It ought not to be done so my brethren.
Does a fountain flow out at one hole sweet and bitter water? Can the fygge
tree my brethren bring forth grapes, or the vine, fygges? Even so another can
salt water give sweet. Who is wise and learned Coloss. 4. a Ephesians. 5. b
show his workynge of his good conversation in the meekness of wisdom. If so
be ye have Romans 1^. b
bitter hatred, and there be contencions in your hearts, rejoice not, and be
not liars against the truth: for this wisdom is not coming down from
above from the father of lights, but earthly, beastly deuelysh. For where as
is envy and contencion, there is inconstancy and every evil work. But ye
wisdom that is from above, is first truly Sap. 6. b
chayste, than peaceable, meke, persuadynge, consenting unto good things, full
of mercy and good fruits, judging without simulacion. But ye fruit of
righteousness is sowe^ in peace, unto the^ ye work peace.

The.iiii. Chapter.
From whence are there wars Gal. 1. b 1. Ioh. ^. c
that the frendshippe of this world is enemy unto God? Whosoever therefore will
be a friend of this world, is made the enemy of god. Think ye that scripture
says for naught: Romans 8. d Gal. 5. c
The sprete that abides in you desires unto envy? But he Pro. 3. b
gives the more grace. Wherefore he says: God 1. Petri. 5. b
resysteth the proud, but gives grace unto ye 1. Petri. 5. a

who art thou that iudgest thy neighbor? Eze. 18. a Luce. 12. b

little, and after that shall it vanysh.) for it that ye do say: Act. ^8. a

The.v. Chapter.
^. ^^m. 6. b
ye rich, weep, howlynge in your wretchednesses, ye which shall come to you.
Your riches are corrupt, your clothes are eaten of mothes, your gold and
silver is rusted, and their rust shall be a witness against you, and shall eat

Mat. 5. a
we count the^ happy that have suffered. Ye have herd of Job. 1. c and.2. b
the patience of Job, and have seen the end of the LORD, that ye LORD is
merciful and pyteous. But Math. 5. d 2. Cori. 1. c
swear not, another by heaven, nor by earth, nor any what soever oath else. But
let your oath be: ye, ye: nay, nay, that ye do not fall under judgment. And
if any of you be sorry, let him pray: If he be merry, let him also sing
psalms. If any among you be sick, let him bring in the Elders of the
congregation, and let them pray over him, Marc. 6. b
anoyntynge him with oil in the name of the LORD: and the prayer of faith
shall save the sick, and the LORD shall raise him up: and if he be in sins,
they shall be forgiven him. Knowledge your sins therefore one to another, and
pray for each other, that ye may be saved: for the instau^te prayer of the
ryghteous is much worth. ^. Reg. 17. a Luc. 4. c
Elias was a mortal man like unto us, and in prayer he prayed that it should
not rain upon earth, and it rayned not in three year and six months. ^.
Reg. 18. a
And he prayed again, and ye sky gave rain, and the earth gave her fruit. My
brethren if any of you shall err from the truth, and any man shall convert
him, he must know that he that causes a sinner to convert from the error
of his way, he shall save his soul from death, and shall cover the multitude
of sins.

The end of ye canonical Epistle of to the Apostle James.

The end of the first canonical Epistle of Peter the Apostle.
The second canonical Epistle of Peter the Apostle.
The first Chapter.
God, and the saueoure Jesus Christ 1. Petri. 1. a
Grace be unto you and peace be fulfilled in the knowledge of God, and Christ
Jesus our LORD. As all things of the godly power, which [belonge] unto life
and godliness are given unto us, by his knowledge, which has called us by his
own glory and power, by whom he has given us great and precious promyses,
that thereby ye become Ioh 1. a Coloss. 2. ^
partakers of the Godly nature, flyenge the corrupcion of ye desire, which is
in ye world. But ye applyenge all care, ministre 1. Cori. 8. a.
in knowledge, abstine^ce: in abstinence, patience: in patience, Godliness: in
Godliness, love of brotherheade: in love of brotherhead charity. For if these
be with you, and be ple^teous, they shall make you not void and without fruit
in ye knowledge of our LORD Jesus Christ. For he that has not these things,
he is blind and gropynge with the hand, forgetting the clensynge of his old
sins. Wherefore brethren endeavor ye the more that ye make sure your calling
and choosing with good works: for doing these things ye shall not sin at
any time. For so shall an entrance into the everlasting kingdom of our LORD
and Saueoure Jesus Christ be ministered unto you plentyfully. Luce. 22. ^
Wherefore I shall begin to admonyshe 2. Corin. 5. a
tabernacle to raise you in the admonicion, Ioh. 21. ^ 1. Tim. 4. a
being sure that the layenge down of my tabernacle shall be quick, according
also as our LORD Jesus Christ has showed me. Ye and I will give diligence,
and that often, yt yt may have after my death that ye make a remembrance of all
these things. For we have not made known unto you the power and foreknowlege
of our LORD Jesus Christ, having followed rude fables Ioha^. 1. b ^. Ioh. 1. a
but being become the beholders Math. 17. a Marc. 9. a. Luc. 9. d.
This is my beloved son in who^ I have delight, hear him. And this voice have
we herd brought from heaven, when we were with him upon the holy mount. And
we have a sure word of prophecye, unto the which ye do well geuynge head, as
unto a light ^. Cor. 4. b
shynynge in a darcke place, till ye day do rise, and ye morrow star do rise
in your hearts. Knowing this first, yt al ye prophecy of scripture, is not
done by private interpretacio^. Daniel. 9. b zach. 7. b. 2. Tim. 3. b
For the prophecy was never brought by man's will, but the holy men of God have
spoken being inspyred by the holy ghost.

unrighteousness, estymynge the one days voluptuousness a pleasure:
staynynges [they are] and spots, ouerflowynge in pleasures, at their feasts
using excess of you, having eyes full of aduoutrye and vncesseable sin,
entycynge unstable souls* having a heart exercysed in covetousness, children
of curse leaving the right way they have erred, having followed the way of
Number. 22.23 and.24.
Balaam of Bosor, which loved the reward of wickedness, Nu. 31. b
but he had the tame domme b^aste a reprofe of his folly* [for] speaking with
man's voice it forbad the prophets Jude. 1. c
clouds carried with te^pestes, unto whom ye mist of darkness, is reserved.
For speaking with pride of vanite, they entyce into lechery the desires of the
flesh them, which escape a little: they that be conuersau^t in error, them are
they promising lyberte, when they themselves are servants of corrupcion.
Ioha^ 8. c Romans 6. b Luce. 9. f
For of whom any man is overcome: his servant is he also. Ioha^ 8. c Romans 6.
b Luce. 9. f
For if they flyeng ye stayninges of the world in the knowledge of our LORD
and Saueoure Jesus Christ, being tangled with the same are overcome again,
Math. 12. c Hebre. 6. a
than are the latter ends become worse unto them than the first. For it had been better for them not to know the way of ryghteousnes, tha^ after ye
knowledge Actu. 5. a

For ye true proverb is chanced unto them: Prove. ^6. b Eccli. 3^* d
The dog is turned again to his vomit* and the sow being washen, in the
wallowynge of mire.

The.iii. Chapter.
Behold this second Epistle Act. 20. d 1. Tim. 4. a 2. Tim. 3. a Jude. 1. c
that in the last days shall come mockers in deceaueablenesse, walkyng after
their own desires, saying: Ezec. 12. d 2 Thessalonians. 2. a
Where is his promise or his coming? For sense the fathers slepte, all things
do so remain, [as at] the beginning of the creature. For this they know not,
and that wyllyngly, that the heavens were first, Genesis 1. a
and ye earth was being of the water and by the water by the word of God, by
the which things Genesis 7. d
that world that than was, peryshed by water. But the heaven and earth that
are now, are set up again by the same word kept 2 Thessalonians. 1. ^
for the fire unto the day of judgment and destruction of wicked me^. But
let not this one thing Psalm. 89. a Ezech. 12. ^ 1. Petr. 4. a
one day by the LORD, is as a thousa^de years: and a thousand years, as one
day. The LORD does not make long with his promise, as some do suppose: but
he Romans 2. a
behaueth himself patiently because of you, Ezech. ^8. d
not willing any to perysh but all men to come again to repe^tau^ce. Math.
24. d ^. Thessalonians. 5. a Apoc. 3. a
But the day of ye LORD shall come as a thief, Esaias. 51. b Psalm. 101. d
Hebre. 1. b
in the which the heavens shall pass with a great rush, but the elements
shall be lowsed with heat, and the earth and all the works that are therein
shall be burnte. When al these now be to be loused, whar manner of persons ought
ye to be than in holy conuersacions and godlynesses, waiting and haistynge
unto the coming of ye LORDS day, by ye which ye heavens burning shall be
lowsed, and the eleme^tes for heat of the fire shall fayde? Es^^. ^5. c Apoc.
21. a
But we wait for new heavens, and new earth, and Esa. 66. d Math. 13. ^
his promyses, in the which righteousness dwells. in the knowledge of our
LORD and Saueoure Jesus Christ. To him be glory, both now, and in the day of
everlasting. Amen.

The end of the second canonical Epistle of Peter the Apostle.
The first cacanonicall Epistle of Ihon the Apostle.
The first Chapter.
THat which was from Ioh. 1. b 2. Petri. 1. b
we have seen with our eyes, that which we have beholden, and Ioh. 20. d
our hands have handled, of ye word of life, and the life is manifest, and
we have seen and testifye and show unto you Ioha^. 17. a
ye life everlasting which was by the father and appeared unto us. That which
we have seen and have herd do we show unto you, that ye also may have
fellowshippe with us, and yt our fellowship be with the father, and with his

there came one of the seven angels that have the vyals full of the last plages,
and spoke with me, saying: Come, and I shall show the the bryde, the lambs
wife. And he took me up in sprete into a great and high mountain, and showed
me the holy city Jerusalem, coming down from heaven from God, having the
clearness of God: and her light like unto a precious stone eue^ unto a Iaspar
stone, as Crystal. And she had a great and high wall, having twelfe gates, and
in the gates twelfe angels, and names written, which are the names of the
twelfe trybes of the children of Israel. On the East, three gates, and on the
North, three gates: and on the South, three gates: and on the Weste three gates.
And the wall of the city was having twelfe fu^dame^tes, and in the^ the
twelfe names of the twelfe Apostles of ye la^be. zach. 2. a
And building of his wall was of Jasper stone: but the city it self was pure
gold, like unto clean glass. And the foundacions of the wall of ye city
were garnished with every preous stone. The first fou^dacio^ [was] a Iaspar, the
second a Sapphire, the third a Calcedony, ye fourth a Smaragde, the fyfte a
Sardonix, the syxt a Sardius, the seventh a Chrisolitus, the eight a Beral, the
nynth a Topase, the tenth a Chrisoprasus, ye eleventh a Hyacinth, ye twelft an
Amethiste. Esaias. 60. b
And her gates shall not be shut by day: for there shall no night be there, and
they shall bring ye glory and honor of the Heythen in the same. There shall
not enter therein any defiled thing, or workynge abominacio^ or making lie:
save they yt are wryte^ in ye book of life of ye la^be

The.xxii. Chapter.
zacha. 13. a and.14. b
the river of ye living water, shynyng as Cristal, coming out from the seat
of God, and the la^be. In ye mids of his street and on either side of the
river was the tree of life, bryngyng forth twelfe fruits, geuynge his fruit
every month, and the leaves of ye tree are for the health of the Heithe^. And
there shall be no more curse, but the seat of God and the la^be shall be therein, and
his servants shall serve him, and they shall behold his vysage, and his name
shall be in their foreheades. And there shall be no more night, and they shall have
no need of the light of ye burning light nor the light of the Son: for ye
LORD God shall lyghte^ the^, and they shall raygne for ever and ever. And he
said unto me: These words are most faithful and true. And the LORD God of
ye spretes of ye prophets sent his angel to show it unto his servants the
things yt must be done quyckely. And behold, I come quyckely. Happy is he
that keeps ye sayenges of the prophecy of this book: And it is I Ihon that
have herd and seen these things. And after that I had herd and seen [them,]
I fell down, yt I might worship before the fete of the angel, which did
show me these things. And he said unto me: Se you do it not: for I am thy
fellow-seruaunt, and of thy brethren the^ prophets, and of the^ yt keep the
words of the prophecye of this book. Worship God. And he says unto me:
Seal not ye words of the prophecy of this book, for ye time is at hand. He
yt hurts, let him hurt still: and he yt is in fythynesses, let him be fylthy
still: and he yt is ryghteous, let him be more righteous: and [he yt is] holy,
let him be more hallowed. Behold I come quickly, and my reward is with my, to
give unto every man according to his works. I am Alpha and Omega, the first
and last, the beginning and end. Blessed are they yt wash their garments in
the blood of ye lamb, that their power may be in ye tree of life, and yt they
may go into ye city through the gates. Without are dogs and sorcerers, and
unclean persons and murthurers, and Idolatrers, and every one yt loves and
makes lesynge. I Jesus have sent mine angel to testifye these things in ye
co^gregacions I am the root and kynred of David, the shynynge and morning
star. And the sprete and the brydgrome say: Come. And he yt hears, let him
say; Come. And he yt does thyrst, let him come: and he that will, let him take
ye water of life freely. For I testifye unto every one hearing ye words of
this prophecy: If any shall add to these, God shall add upon him the plages
written in this book. And if any man diminish of ye words of the book of this
prophecy, God shall take away his part out of the book of life, and of the
holy city, and of those things yt are written in this book. He that bears
witness of these things, says: Ye I come quickly So be it. Come LORD
Jesus. The grace of our LORD Jesus Christ be with you all. Amen.

The end of the Apocalipse or reuelacion of Ihon the Apostle.
The end of the new Testament.
A table to find the Epistles and Gospels usually red in the church after
Salysbury use, whereof the first line is the Epistle, and the other the Gospel:
whose beginning thou shalt find in the book marked with a cross and the
end with half a cross, contained within the letters namely, A. B. C. D. etc.
